[[File:Dead & Company 1 Nov 2015, New York, New York.jpg |thumb |upright=1.3 |Dead & Company on November 1, 2015 at Madison Square Garden. Front, left to right: Oteil Burbridge, John Mayer, Bob Weir, Jeff Chimenti; Rear, left to right: Bill Kreutzmann, Mickey Hart]] The [[Grateful Dead]] were an American rock band known for their lengthy, partially improvised performances, as well as for a loyal fan base who often followed the band for several shows or entire tours. They disbanded in 1995, following the death of de facto bandleader [[Jerry Garcia]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Joel |last=Selvin |date=December 9, 1995 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/PAGE-ONE-End-of-the-Road-for-Grateful-Dead-3017847.php |title=End of the Road for Grateful Dead – Without Garcia, Band Just Can't Keep Truckin' |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |access-date=July 28, 2017 |quote=Say goodbye to the Grateful Dead. The band announced yesterday that in the wake of guitarist Jerry Garcia's death, it will break up after playing together for 30 years.}}</ref> Since then remaining members have reunited for a number of concert tours and one-off performances, often in very different configurations. The following is a list of instances where former Grateful Dead members have reunited.
Other than Jerry Garcia, the Grateful Dead's main performing members were [[Bob Weir]], [[Phil Lesh]], [[Bill Kreutzmann]] and [[Mickey Hart]]. Garcia, Weir, Lesh and Kreutzmann were in the band from its inception in 1965 until its demise in 1995, while Hart had a tenure of 25 non-consecutive years. The other then-current or former members of the Grateful Dead who were living at the time that the band broke up were [[Vince Welnick]], [[Donna Jean Godchaux]], and [[Tom Constanten]]. Additionally, [[Bruce Hornsby]] was in the lineup for many Dead concerts and was considered an unofficial member of the band. Already deceased in 1995 were [[Ron "Pigpen" McKernan]], [[Keith Godchaux]], and [[Brent Mydland]].
==Tours== [[File:The Dead 6.17.03.jpg |thumb |The Dead at the Virginia Beach Amphitheater on June 17, 2003. Left to right: Phil Lesh, Joan Osborne, Bob Weir, Mickey Hart, Jimmy Herring. Not pictured: Bill Kreutzmann, Jeff Chimenti, Rob Barraco]] [[File:Rhythm-Devils-01.jpg |thumb |The Rhythm Devils at Sam Boyd Stadium in Las Vegas on October 29, 2006. Left to right: Mike Gordon, Bill Kreutzmann, Jen Durkin, Mickey Hart, Steve Kimock, Sikiru Adepoju]] [[File:Furthur 20090918-01.jpg |thumb| Furthur at the Fox Theatre in Oakland on September 18, 2009. Left to right: Phil Lesh, Bob Weir, Joe Russo, Jay Lane, John Kadlecik. Not pictured: Jeff Chimenti]] ===The Other Ones=== {{Main|The Other Ones}} *In 1998 guitarist [[Bob Weir]], bassist [[Phil Lesh]], drummer [[Mickey Hart]] and touring keyboardist [[Bruce Hornsby]] formed a band called the Other Ones.<ref>{{cite web |date=May 2012 |url=http://www.deaddisc.com/GDFD_Other_Ones.htm |title=The Other Ones |website=Grateful Dead Family Discography |access-date=September 10, 2017}}</ref> They toured America with guitarists [[Steve Kimock]] and [[Mark Karan]], saxophonist [[Dave Ellis (saxophonist)|Dave Ellis]], and drummer [[John Molo]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Ari |last=Bendersky |date=June 6, 1998 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5929573/former_dead_members_premiere_new_lineup_in_san_francisco |title=Former Dead Members Premiere New Lineup in San Francisco |website=Rolling Stone |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725132726/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5929573/former_dead_members_premiere_new_lineup_in_san_francisco |archive-date=July 25, 2009 |access-date=July 2, 2017}}</ref> A live album from this tour, ''[[The Strange Remain]]'', was released in 1999. *In 2000 the Other Ones launched another tour featuring former Grateful Dead members Weir, Hart, Hornsby and drummer [[Bill Kreutzmann]]. Lesh declined to participate and was replaced by [[Alphonso Johnson]]. Steve Kimock and Mark Karan continued their roles as co-lead guitarists.<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Parrish |date=September 4, 2000 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-09-04/features/0009040258_1_mark-karan-grateful-dead-dead-bassist-phil-lesh |title=Other Ones' New Lineup Still Developing Identity |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |access-date=September 9, 2017}}</ref> *In 2002 an Other Ones line-up of Bob Weir, Phil Lesh, Bill Kreutzmann and Mickey Hart toured the United States with guitarist [[Jimmy Herring]], keyboardists [[Jeff Chimenti]] and [[Rob Barraco]], and vocalist [[Susan Tedeschi]]. This was the first time that Weir, Lesh, Kreutzmann, and Hart had toured together since 1995.<ref>{{cite news |first=Joel |last=Selvin |date=December 1, 2002 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Other-Ones-reunite-Former-Grateful-Dead-mates-2749192.php |title=Other Ones Reunite; Former Grateful Dead Mates Patch Things Up |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |access-date=September 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Tony |last=Bonyata |date= |url=http://www.concertlivewire.com/otherones.htm |title=Grateful Dead's Long Strange Trip Carries On: Terrapin Station Featuring The Other Ones |website=Concert Live Wire |access-date=March 25, 2018}}</ref>
===The Dead=== {{Main|The Dead (band)}} *In 2003 the Other Ones changed their name to the Dead.<ref>{{cite web |date=May 2012 |url=http://www.deaddisc.com/GDFD_Dead.htm |title=The Dead |website=Grateful Dead Family Discography |access-date=September 10, 2017}}</ref> The line-up of Weir, Lesh, Kreutzmann, Hart, Jimmy Herring (guitar), Jeff Chimenti (keyboards), and Rob Barraco (keyboards) toured America again, with [[Joan Osborne]] replacing Susan Tedeschi on backing vocals.<ref>{{cite news |first=Joel |last=Selvin |date=February 12, 2003 |url=http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/02/12/MN228379.DTL |title=Marin Icons Now the Dead |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=July 2, 2017}}</ref> *In 2004 the Dead again toured the U.S. Supporting Weir, Lesh, Kreutzmann and Hart were [[Warren Haynes]] (guitar), Jimmy Herring (guitar), and Jeff Chimenti (keyboards).<ref>{{cite news |first=Joel |last=Selvin |date=June 28, 2004 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/music/article/Maybe-it-s-true-the-Dead-will-always-be-with-us-2745808.php |title=Maybe It's True the Dead Will Always Be With Us -- Weir, Lesh and Company Keep the Spirit Alive |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |access-date=September 10, 2017}}</ref> *In 2009 the Dead toured America with a lineup of Weir, Lesh, Kreutzmann, Hart, Warren Haynes, and Jeff Chimenti.<ref>{{cite news |first=Joel |last=Selvin |date=May 12, 2009 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/music/article/Music-review-The-Dead-show-life-at-Shoreline-3242418.php |title=Music Review: The Dead Show Life at Shoreline |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |access-date=September 10, 2017}}</ref>
===The Rhythm Devils=== {{Main|Rhythm Devils}} *In 2006, Mickey Hart and Bill Kreutzmann re-formed the Rhythm Devils, a percussion-based ensemble that had played intermittently when the Grateful Dead were still together. The band went on tour with a lineup including [[Sikiru Adepoju]] (drums and percussion), [[Steve Kimock]] (guitar), [[Mike Gordon]] (bass), and [[Jen Durkin]] (vocals).<ref>{{cite web |date=September 15, 2006 |url=https://glidemagazine.com/8000/rhythm-devils-launch-theater-tour/ |title=Rhythm Devils Launch Theater Tour |website=Glide Magazine |access-date=July 2, 2017}}</ref> They subsequently released a video of the tour, called ''[[The Rhythm Devils Concert Experience]]''. *In 2010 Hart and Kreutzmann again toured as the Rhythm Devils. Their band featured Sikiru Adepoju (drums and percussion), [[Davy Knowles]] (guitar), and [[Andy Hess]] (bass), with multi-instrumentalists [[Keller Williams]] for the first part of the tour and [[Tim Bluhm]] for the second part.<ref>{{cite web |date=May 27, 2010 |url=http://www.kindweb.com/News/article.asp?ID=11463 |title=Rhythm Devils Featuring Mickey Hart and Bill Kreutzmann Announce Summer Tour |website=KindWeb |access-date=July 2, 2017}}</ref>
===Furthur=== {{Main|Furthur (band)}} *In 2009 Bob Weir and Phil Lesh formed a new band called Furthur,<ref>{{cite web |date=April 2013 |url=http://www.deaddisc.com/GDFD_Furthur.htm |title=Furthur |website=Grateful Dead Family Discography |access-date=September 10, 2017}}</ref> with [[John Kadlecik]] (guitar), [[Jeff Chimenti]] (keyboards), [[Joe Russo (musician)|Joe Russo]] (drums), and [[Jay Lane]] (drums). A few months later [[Sunshine Becker]] and [[Zoe Ellis]] were added to the lineup as backing vocalists.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dead Behind, Furthur Ahead |first=Dean |last=Budnick |website=Relix |date=March 2011 |url=http://www.relix.com:80/features/2011/11/04/dead-behind-furthur-ahead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107200836/http://www.relix.com/features/2011/11/04/dead-behind-furthur-ahead |archivedate=November 7, 2011 |accessdate=July 2, 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *In 2010 the band continued touring. In the spring, Lane and Ellis left the group, and [[Jeff Pehrson]] (backing vocals) joined. *In 2011, 2012, and 2013, Furthur continued as before playing several tours each year with the lineup of Bob Weir, Phil Lesh, John Kadlecik, Jeff Chimenti, Joe Russo, Sunshine Becker, and Jeff Pehrson.
===Fare Thee Well=== {{Main|Fare Thee Well: Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead}} *In 2015, Weir, Lesh, Kreutzmann and Hart performed two concerts (June 27 and 28) at [[Levi Stadium]] in [[Santa Clara, California]], and three concerts (July 3, 4, and 5) at [[Soldier Field]] in [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]], to celebrate the Grateful Dead's 50th anniversary. They were joined by [[Trey Anastasio]] on guitar and [[Bruce Hornsby]] and [[Jeff Chimenti]] on keyboards. The performances were billed as "Fare Thee Well: Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead".<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Pareles |date=July 6, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/07/arts/music/no-song-left-unsung-grateful-dead-plays-its-last.html |title=Review: No Song Left Unsung, Grateful Dead Plays Its Last |newspaper=New York Times |access-date=July 2, 2017}}</ref> The concerts were advertised as the final time Weir, Lesh, Kreutzmann and Hart would perform together. Later that year, a live recording of ''[[Fare Thee Well: Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead (album)|Fare Thee Well]]'' was released as an album.
===Dead & Company=== {{Main|Dead & Company}} *[[Dead & Company 2015 Tour]]: After the Fare Thee Well concerts, Weir, Kreutzmann, and Hart joined forces with singer and guitarist [[John Mayer]] in a band called Dead & Company. With Lesh declining to commit to another rigorous tour, former [[Allman Brothers Band]] bassist [[Oteil Burbridge]] was recruited to join, as well as keyboardist [[Jeff Chimenti]]. The band played a 22-concert tour in October, November, and Decmember 2015. Although some Deadheads were initially skeptical of Mayer's inclusion, the band's performances were well-received.<ref name=Nev11.27.A>{{Citation |last=Taylor |first=John |date=December 1, 2015 |title=Review + Photos: Dead & Company: A Tale of Two Shows in One Night at MGM Grand |newspaper=Las Vegas Sun|url=http://lasvegassun.com/vegasdeluxe/2015/dec/01/review-photos-dead-company-a-tale-of-two-shows-one/ |accessdate=April 8, 2016 |quote="With superb guitar skills and strong vocals on several titles ("West L.A. Fadeaway" and "Deal", among them), Mayer continued to win over the army of itinerant Deadheads in the audience Saturday night."}}</ref> *[[Dead & Company Summer Tour 2016]]: In June and July 2016, Dead & Company played a concert tour of 24 shows. Before the tour began, both Mayer and Weir expressed optimism about the band's future; Mayer said he "will never close the door on Dead & Company, ever" while Weir envisioned future lineups of the band performing long after he, Hart and Kreutzmann are gone.<ref name="never-close">{{Cite web |title=John Mayer Says He'll 'Never Close the Door on Dead & Company, Ever' |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7326306/john-mayer-grateful-dead-company-interview |website=Billboard |accessdate=May 18, 2016 |first=Gary |last=Graff |date=April 7, 2016}}</ref> *[[Dead & Company Summer Tour 2017]]: In May, June, and July 2017, the band again toured the country, playing a total of 20 shows.<ref>{{cite web |first=Althea |last= Legaspi |date=December 1, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/dead-company-detail-2017-summer-tour-w453415 |title=Dead & Company Detail 2017 Summer Tour |website=Rolling Stone |access-date=September 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Jeffrey |last=Greenblatt |date=July 2, 2017 |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/pro-fan-shot-video-dead-company-close-summer-tour-wrigley-field |title=Pro & Fan-Shot Video: Dead & Company Closes Out Summer Tour at Wrigley Field |website=JamBase |access-date=September 8, 2017}}</ref> *[[Dead & Company Fall Tour 2017]]: The band played 13 concerts in November and December 2017.<ref>{{cite web |first=Jon |last=Blistein |date=September 7, 2017 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/dead-company-detail-fall-tour-w501739 |title=Dead & Company Detail Fall Tour |website=Rolling Stone |access-date=September 7, 2017}}</ref> Three additional shows were postponed while John Mayer recovered from an appendectomy.<ref>{{cite web |first=Dave |last=Brooks |date=December 6, 2017 |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8061778/john-mayer-recovering-surgery-dead-company-postponed |title=John Mayer Recovering from Surgery, Remaining Dead & Company Shows Postponed |website=Billboard |access-date=December 12, 2017}}</ref> *[[Dead & Company Summer Tour 2018]]: The band played a 24-concert tour of the U.S. in May, June, and July 2018.<ref>{{cite web |first= Wandera |last=Hussein |date=January 18, 2018 |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/8094919/dead-and-company-tour-2018-dates |title=Dead & Company Announce 19-City Summertime Tour |website=Billboard |access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref>
==Single shows and other collaborations== [[File:Bobby & Phil Duo, Chicago Theatre, Chicago, IL, 3-10-18 - 5.jpg |thumb |A "Bobby & Phil" concert at the Chicago Theatre, March 10, 2018. Left to right: Jeff Chimenti, Wally Ingram, Bob Weir, Teresa Williams, Phil Lesh, Larry Campbell]] *Vince Welnick was a member of Bob Weir's band [[RatDog]] from September to December 1995, playing in a total of 14 concerts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ratdog.org/band/ |title=Bob Weir & RatDog Band Members |website=ratdog.org |access-date=November 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Iwasaki |date=December 4, 1995 |url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/454415/RATDOG-REVUES-CLEAN-RAW-SOUND-STRIKES-A-CHORD-WITH-SL-CROWD.html |title=Ratdog Revue's Clean, Raw Sound Strikes a Chord with S.L. Crowd |website=Deseret News |access-date=November 23, 2018}}</ref> Mickey Hart, Bill Kreutzmann, Donna Jean Godchaux and Bruce Hornsby have all guested with RatDog at different times. *On April 12, 1996, Phil Lesh and Bob Weir joined the Bruce Hornsby Band for the four final songs of the concert, including three Grateful Dead standards and a cover of [[the Band]]'s "[[The Weight]]". *In June 1996, Phil Lesh, Bob Weir, Mickey Hart, and Vince Welnick joined the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra for three consecutive concerts, performing [[John Cage]]'s ''Renga'' on the first two nights, and an improvisational "Space" segment dedicated to American composer [[Henry Cowell]] on the third night. *In the summer of 1996, the first Furthur Festival toured the United States. Each concert featured performances by multiple bands, including Bob Weir and RatDog, Mickey Hart's Mystery Box, and Bruce Hornsby and his band, along with [[Hot Tuna]] and [[Los Lobos]]. Weir, Hart, and Hornsby often played together in a jam session at the end of each show, and sometimes sat in with each other's bands for a few songs. They were joined at the [[Shoreline Amphitheatre]] show by Phil Lesh.<ref>{{cite book |first=Blair |last=Jackson |title=Garcia: An American Life |publisher=Penguin Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-670-88660-2 |pages=468–469}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=John |last=Metzger |date=July 1996 |url=http://www.musicbox-online.com/ff-il-96.html |title=The Bus Came By... |website=The Music Box |access-date=November 18, 2018}}</ref> *On March 6, 1997, Bob Weir and Phil Lesh joined the David Murray Octet for several songs at [[The Fillmore]] in San Francisco. *In the summer of 1997, the second Further Festival toured the country. The bands at each show included Bob Weir and RatDog, Mickey Hart and Planet Drum, and Bruce Hornsby, along with [[the Black Crowes]] and [[Moe (band)|Moe]]. [[Robert Hunter (lyricist)|Robert Hunter]] also performed at several of the shows. As on the previous year's tour, Weir, Hart, and Hornsby performed some songs together, and were joined at Shoreline by Phil Lesh.<ref>Jackson, pp. 471–472</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=John |last=Metzger |date=August 1997 |url=http://www.musicbox-online.com/ff-il-97.html |title=Beyond and Before |website=The Music Box |access-date=November 18, 2018}}</ref> *On July 25, 1998, at Shoreline Amphitheatre – the last show of the 1998 Furthur Festival tour – Bill Kreutzmann sat in for part of the performance by [[the Other Ones]]. It was the first time that Weir, Lesh, Hart, and Kreutzmann had played together since 1995.<ref>{{cite web |first=Shawn |last=Perry |url=http://vintagerock.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=258 |title=Furthur Festival – July 25, 1998 – Mountain View, CA |website=vintagerock.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911023942/http://vintagerock.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=258 |archive-date=September 11, 2017 |access-date=November 18, 2018}}</ref> *On November 6, 1998, Phil Lesh guested with Bruce Hornsby's band to perform a few songs which included versions of "Scarlet Begonias" and "Tennessee Jed." *Bob Weir and Phil Lesh have sung the [[The Star-Spangled Banner|national anthem]] before several [[San Francisco Giants]] baseball games. On September 30, 1999, at the last Giants game at [[Candlestick Park]], they sang it together with Donna Jean Godchaux.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ron |last=Kroichick |date=October 1, 1999 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/sports/kroichick/article/FAREWELL-CANDLESTICK-Stick-s-Last-Day-2905122.php |title=Farewell, Candlestick: 'Stick's Last Day |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> Weir and Lesh sang the national anthem for Grateful Dead Tribute Night on August 9, 2010. That night Mickey Hart and [[Bill Walton]] led the crowd in singing "[[Take Me Out to the Ball Game]]".<ref>{{cite news |first=Paul |last=White |date=August 10, 2010 |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/dailypitch/post/2010/08/san-francisco-giants-keep-truckin-on-grateful-dead-tribute-night/1 |title=San Francisco Giants Keep Truckin' on Grateful Dead Tribute Night |newspaper=USA Today |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> Weir and Lesh sang the national anthem again on October 15, 2012, a playoff game for the Giants who were on their way to winning the [[2012 World Series|World Series]].<ref>{{cite news |author=CBS/AP |date=October 15, 2012 |url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2012/10/15/giants-defeat-cardinals-in-game-2-tie-nlcs/ |title=Giants Defeat Cardinals in Game 2, Tie NLCS |newspaper=CBS San Francisco |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> They sang it again on October 14, 2014, another playoff game en route to another [[2014 World Series|world championship]] for the Giants.<ref>{{cite news |author=AP |date=October 14, 2014 |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grateful-dead/6281764/grateful-deads-phil-lesh-bob-weir-sing-national-anthem-at-ball |title=Grateful Dead's Phil Lesh & Bob Weir Sing National Anthem at Ball Game |newspaper=Billboard |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> The precedent for these patriotic performances occurred when the Grateful Dead were still together and Jerry Garcia, Bob Weir, and Vince Welnick sang the national anthem before the Giants game on April 12, 1993.<ref>{{cite web |first=Dan |last=Colman |date=March 28, 2013 |url=http://www.openculture.com/2013/03/grateful_dead_rocks_the_national_anthem.html |title=The Grateful Dead Rock the National Anthem at Candlestick Park: Opening Day, 1993 |website=Open Culture |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *On December 31, 1999, Bill Kreutzmann and Mickey Hart joined Bob Weir and Ratdog for a few songs. Ratdog members Mark Karan, Dave Ellis, bassist [[Rob Wasserman]] and keyboardist [[Jeff Chimenti]] backed the three for the first song played. Then Karan, Wasserman and Chimenti were replaced by guitarist [[Jorma Kaukonen]], bassist [[Jack Casady]] and keyboardist [[Pete Sears]] for three songs. *On June 6, 2001, at [[Sweetwater Saloon]] in [[Mill Valley, California]], Bob Weir, Phil Lesh, Jimmy Herring, Rob Barraco and John Molo played a show as the Crusader Rabbit Stealth Band. On December 31, 2001, at the [[Kaiser Convention Center|Kaiser Auditorium]] in [[Oakland, California]], the Crusader Rabbit Stealth Band performed again, this time with a lineup of [[Phil Lesh and Friends]] (Phil Lesh, Warren Haynes, Jimmy Herring, Rob Barraco, and John Molo), Bob Weir, Bill Kreutzmann, and Mickey Hart.<ref>{{cite web |date=June 2009 |url=http://www.deaddisc.com/GDFD_Crusader_Rabbit.htm |title=Crusader Rabbit Stealth Band |website=Grateful Dead Family Discography |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=December 4, 2010 |url=http://www.deadheadland.com/2010/12/04/crusader-rabbit-stealth-band-take-a-step-back-to-2001/ |title=Crusader Rabbit Stealth Band – Take a Step Back to 2001 |website=Deadheadland |access-date=September 23, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Blair |last=Jackson |date=December 2011 |url=http://www.dead.net/features/blair-jackson/blair%E2%80%99s-golden-road-blog-finding-new-year%E2%80%99s-magic-post-gd-world |title=Blair's Golden Road Blog – Finding New Year's Magic in a Post-GD World |website=dead.net |access-date=September 23, 2017}}</ref> *On July 23, 2002, Bob Weir and Bill Kreutzmann joined [[Phil Lesh & Friends]] for one set. Phil Lesh & Friends guitarists [[Warren Haynes]] and [[Jimmy Herring]], drummer John Molo and keyboardist [[Rob Barraco]] supported the three musicians. *On September 25, 2005, Weir, Kreutzmann, Hart, Bruce Hornsby and vocalist [[Donna Jean Godchaux]] performed together at the Comes A Time tribute to Jerry Garcia. They were supported by many musicians who came and went through all the songs performed. Notable performers were guitarists [[Jimmy Herring]], [[Warren Haynes]] and [[Trey Anastasio]], and vocalists Gloria Jones and Jackie LaBranch. Bass duties were shared by [[Robin Sylvester]] and J.V. Collier.<ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Shulimson |date=October 10, 2005 |url=http://www.jambands.com/reviews/shows/2005/10/10/comes-a-time-a-tribute-to-jerry-garcia-greek-theatre-berkeley-ca-9-24 |title=Comes A Time: A Tribute to Jerry Garcia, Greek Theatre, Berkeley, CA- 9/24 |website=jambands.com |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *On August 19, 2006, Bob Weir joined Bill Kreutzmann and Mickey Hart during the [[Rhythm Devils]] set at the [[Gathering of the Vibes]]. Remaining members of the Rhythm Devils Steve Kimock, bassist [[Mike Gordon]] and vocalist Jen Durkin played with them. *On January 4, 2007, Weir, Kreutzmann, Hart and Bruce Hornsby reunited to perform at a fundraiser for speaker of the house [[Nancy Pelosi]]. They were joined by Warren Haynes and Mike Gordon. *On February 4, 2008, Weir, Lesh and Hart performed a concert called [[Deadheads for Obama]] to raise support for presidential candidate [[Barack Obama]]. Supporting musicians were John Molo, keyboardist Steve Molitz and guitarists Mark Karan, [[Barry Sless]] and [[Jackie Greene]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Joel |last=Selvin |date=February 5, 2008 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/grateful-dead-reunite-for-barack-obama-benefit-show-20080205 |title=Grateful Dead Reunite for Barack Obama Benefit Show |website=Rolling Stone |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *On October 12, 2008, Bob Weir, Phil Lesh, Bill Kreutzmann and Mickey Hart performed a concert at [[Penn State University]] called [[Deadheads for Obama#Change Rocks|Change Rocks]] to raise support for presidential candidate Barack Obama. They were supported by Warren Haynes and Jeff Chimenti. The concert was seen as a follow up to the Deadheads for Obama show earlier that year and it sparked a tour that commenced in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |first=John |last=Clarke |date=October 14, 2008 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/the-dead-reunite-for-obama-at-scorching-penn-state-benefit-gig-20081014 |title=The Dead Reunite for Obama at Scorching Penn State Benefit Gig |website=Rolling Stone |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *Bob Weir has joined [[Phil Lesh & Friends]] on several occasions. Bob Weir & RatDog and Phil Lesh & Friends shared a bill at two shows on December 30 and December 31, 2008. Both performances saw Weir and Lesh playing a brief set as a trio with either [[Jay Lane]] or John Molo depending on the night. The New Year's Eve show saw a post-midnight set by a band composed of Bob Weir and Phil Lesh along with several members of Phil Lesh & Friends. Bill Kreutzmann and Donna Jean Godchaux has also guested with Phil and his band. *On January 18, 2009, Bob Weir and Mickey Hart played at a brunch benefit for [[Al Franken]] in [[Washington D.C.]] This was two days prior to the Dead playing a show at the Mid-Atlantic Ball for president Barack Obama. *On January 20, 2009, the Dead lineup of Weir, Lesh, Kreutzmann, Hart, Haynes and Chimenti played two sets in [[Washington D.C.]] at the Mid-Atlantic Inaugural ball for President Barack Obama.<ref>{{cite web |first=Andy |last=Kahn |date=January 20, 2017 |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/dead-perform-mid-atlantic-inaugural-ball-2009 |title=The Dead Perform at Mid-Atlantic Inaugural Ball in 2009 |website=JamBase |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *On February 18 and 19, 2009, Bob Weir and Phil Lesh made guest appearances at Jackie Greene concerts. The two played brief sets as a trio with Greene in between sets by the Jackie Greene Band. On the 19th Weir and Lesh joined Jackie's band their closing set. *On March 28, 2009, Bob Weir and Phil Lesh sat in with [[the Allman Brothers Band]] during the final show of their 2009 run at the [[Beacon Theatre (New York City)|Beacon Theater]]. They performed "Sugaree," "I Know You Rider," and "Franklin's Tower" with the Allmans during the beginning of the second set. *On March 30, 2009, the Dead played three free shows in New York City. Tickets were made available to fans through a contest that lasted three hours on March 27, 2009. Weir, Lesh and Haynes played an acoustic set at the [[Angel Orensanz Center]] followed by a full band set at the [[Gramercy Theatre]] three hours later and a final show at the [[Roseland Ballroom]]. Earlier that day Weir, Lesh and Haynes performed an acoustic version of "Friend of the Devil" on [[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]. *On October 30, 2011, Weir and Hart joined Kreutzmann's band [[7 Walkers]] on stage. It was the first time that Kreutzmann and Weir played together since [[The Dead (band)|the Dead]] dissolved in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |date=October 30, 2011 |url=http://www.jambands.com/news/2011/10/30/bob-weir-and-mickey-hart-to-join-7-walkers-sunday-night |title=Bob Weir and Mickey Hart to Join 7 Walkers Sunday Night |website=jambands.com |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *On August 3, 2012, Bob Weir and a rotating lineup of musicians performed a concert at [[TRI Studios]] in [[San Rafael, California]] called "Move Me Brightly: Celebrating Jerry Garcia's 70th Birthday". These musical artists included Phil Lesh, [[Donna Jean Godchaux]], [[Jeff Chimenti]], [[Joe Russo (musician)|Joe Russo]], and [[Mike Gordon]]. A concert video called ''[[Move Me Brightly]]'' was released in 2013.<ref name=RollingStoneFilm>Brown, Harley (October 28, 2013). [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/jerry-garcia-gets-birthday-tribute-in-move-me-brightly-premiere-20131028 "Jerry Garcia Gets Birthday Tribute in ''Move Me Brightly''], ''Rolling Stone''. Retrieved July 19, 2015.</ref> *On May 14, 2015, Weir, Kreutzmann and Hart performed a version of "Fire On the Mountain" together with a house band and with [[Jimmy Cliff]] singing lead vocals. This was one of many performances at a concert called "Dear Jerry: Celebrating the Music of Jerry Garcia." More songs were performed by the musicians individually as well as with other collaborations and groups, including Phil Lesh's band Communion.<ref>{{cite web |first=Richard |last=Gehr |date=October 14, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/review-dear-jerry-celebrating-the-music-of-jerry-garcia-w444798 |title=Review: 'Dear Jerry' Celebrates Garcia with All-Star Live Concert |website=Rolling Stone |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *Bob Weir joined Bill Kreutzmann's [[Billy & the Kids]] at [[the Peach Music Festival]] in August 2015.<ref>{{cite web |first=Bill |last=Grenfell |date=August 16, 2015 |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/bob-weir-makes-billy-the-kids-debut-at-peach-music-festival |title=Bob Weir Makes Billy & The Kids Debut at Peach Music Festival |website=JamBase |access-date=July 5, 2016}}</ref> *On September 12, 2015, Bob Weir joined Bill Kreutzmann's band [[Billy & the Kids]] for their entire set at the third annual [[Lockn' Festival]]. Mickey Hart joined the band on drums for their final two songs, "One More Saturday Night" and "Not Fade Away." Although Phil Lesh did not perform with the trio, this set was followed immediately by a set from [[Phil Lesh & Friends]] which also featured [[Carlos Santana]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Bernstein |date=September 13, 2015 |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/lockn-lowdown-grateful-dead-core-four-stars-separately-together |title=Lockn' Lowdown: Grateful Dead Core Four Stars Separately & Together |website=JamBase |access-date=July 4, 2017}}</ref> *On May 3, 2017, Bob Weir and Phil Lesh played a concert at [[Terrapin Crossroads]] in [[San Rafael, California]], accompanied by Jason Crosby, Grahame Lesh, and [[Scott Law]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Bernstein |date=May 4, 2017 |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/bob-weir-phil-lesh-team-terrapin-crossroads |title=Bob Weir & Phil Lesh Team Up at Terrapin Crossroads |website=JamBase |access-date=December 12, 2017}}</ref> *On August 25, 2017, Bob Weir joined part of the performance of Phil Lesh and the Terrapin Family Band at the [[Lockn' Festival]] in [[Arrington, Virginia]]. [[Nicki Bluhm]] also sat in on some of the songs. The band featured Jason Crosby, Grahame Lesh, Ross James, and Alex Koford. <ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Bernstein |date=August 26, 2017 |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/phil-lesh-terrapin-family-band-team-warren-haynes-bob-weir-nicki-bluhm-lockn |title=Phil Lesh & Terrapin Family Band Team with Warren Haynes, Bob Weir & Nicki Bluhm wt Lockn' |website=JamBase |access-date=December 12, 2017}}</ref> *In March 2018 Bob Weir and Phil Lesh played a three-city, six-concert tour, billed as "Bobby and Phil".<ref>{{cite web |first=Jesse |last=Jarnow |date=March 5, 2018 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/live-reviews/bob-weir-phil-lesh-trey-anastasio-radio-city-live-review-w517460 |title=Bob Weir and Phil Lesh Get Thrillingly Loose at New York Tour Openers |website=Rolling Stone |access-date=May 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Andy |last=Kahn |date=March 8, 2018 |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/larry-campbell-teresa-williams-join-bob-weir-phil-lesh-in-boston-setlist-video |title=Larry Campbell & Teresa Williams Join Bob Weir & Phil Lesh in Boston |website=JamBase |access-date=May 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Daniel |last=Ojeda |date=March 12, 2018 |url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/features/reviews/bob-weir-phil-lesh-chicago2-finale/ |title=Bob Weir & Phil Lesh Close Duo Tour with Full Band of Grateful Guests in Chicago |website=Live For Live Music |access-date=May 5, 2018}}</ref>

Arts and entertainment |company =[[Rotana Group]]) |publisher = Rotana Audio and Video Company |firstdate = 2005 |country= [[Saudi Arabia]] |based = [[Riyadh]] |language = [[Arabic]] |website =[http://www.rotanamagz.com/ rotanamagz.com] |issn = }} '''''Rotana Magazine''''' (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] مجلة روتانا pronounced Majallat Rotana) is a [[Arab World|pan-Arab]] arts and entertainment weekly magazine published in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] by [[Rotana Group]] owned by Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]].{{cite web|title=Rotana Magazine|url=http://www.rotana.net/corp/static/28/detail|publisher=Rotana Corporate|accessdate=6 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617134312/http://www.rotana.net/corp/static/28/detail|archivedate=17 June 2012|df=dmy-all}} It is distributed across [[MENA region|the entire MENA region]]. ==History== The magazine was launched in 2005 as ''Rotana''.[http://www.emediasearch.com/adrates/1757.pdf eMedia Research] The publisher is the Rotana Audio and Video company based in [[Riyadh]]. Hala Al Nasser was appointed editor-in-chief of the weekly in 2006, being the first woman to hold this post in the country.{{cite journal|last=Sakr|first=Naomi|authorlink=Naomi Sakr|title=Women and Media in Saudi Arabia: Rhetoric, Reductionism and Realities|journal=British Journal of Middle Eastern Studies|year=2008|volume=35|issue=3|pages=385–404|doi=10.1080/13530190802525197}} The magazine was renamed ''Rotana Magazine'' in the 2010-2011 period. ==Contents== The magazine publishes articles by famous writers concerning beauty and fashion, celebrity news, society events, culture, health, interior design, comics, cinema, theatre, food, technology, astrology and more. Addressed mainly to Arab youth and Arab women in the Middle East, the Arab World and the Arab diaspora, the journal includes music and arts news and sections for beauty, fashion and family life. It also serves at the same time as the marketing wing for Rotana Records and dozens of its signed artists. ==See also== *[[List of magazines in Saudi Arabia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2005 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2005]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Rotana Group]] [[Category:Arab media]] [[Category:Arabic-language magazines]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian magazines]] [[Category:Women's magazines]] [[Category:Media in Riyadh]]

{{redirect|Lowtax|Byron (Low Tax) Looper|Byron Looper}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = Something Awful | logo = [[File:Something Awful logo.png|Something Awful grenade logo]] | company_type = [[Limited liability company]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1999}} | location = [[Pleasant Hill, Missouri|Pleasant Hill]], [[Missouri]], [[U.S.]] | key_people = Richard Kyanka
Zack Parsons
David Thorpe | industry = [[Internet industry|Internet]] | products = | revenue = | num_employees = | alexa = {{increase}} 5,277 ({{as of|2017|8|24|alt=August 2017}}){{cite web|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/somethingawful.com |title=SomethingAwful.com Site Info | publisher=[[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate=2017-08-24}} | homepage = {{url|somethingawful.com}} | founder = Richard Charles Kyanka }} '''Something Awful''' ('''SA''') is a [[comedy]] [[website]] housing a variety of content, including [[blog]] entries, [[Internet forum|forums]], feature articles, digitally edited pictures, and humorous media reviews. It was created by Richard "Lowtax" Kyanka in 1999 as a largely personal website, but as it grew, so did its contributors and content. The website has helped to perpetuate various [[Internet phenomenon|Internet phenomena]],{{cite web|title=Tourist of Death|url=http://www.touristofdeath.com/|accessdate=November 24, 2006}}{{unreliable source?|date=January 2013}}{{cite news|title=All your base...|url=https://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4143466,00.html|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|date=February 28, 2001|accessdate=November 24, 2006 | location=London | first=Rich | last=Johnston}}{{cite web|title=All Your Base Are Belong To Frogstar|url=http://frogstar.com/aybabtu/aa-history.asp|accessdate=November 24, 2006}} and it has been cited as an influence on [[Internet culture]].{{cite video | people = David Thorpe, [[Kevin Pereira]] | title = Somethingawful.com, Pink Five, Chris Gore | medium = television | publisher = G4 television | location = |date=July 5, 2005}} In 2018, [[Gizmodo]] placed it as 89th on their list of "100 Websites That Shaped the Internet as We Know It".[https://gizmodo.com/100-websites-that-shaped-the-internet-as-we-know-it-1829634771 100 Websites That Shaped the Internet as We Know It] The website has been involved in a number of notable events. These include a conflict with the [[Spam Prevention Early Warning System]], a [[Hurricane Katrina]] relief fund being caught in [[PayPal]]'s [[red tape]],{{cite web|url=http://www.systemshock.co.za/forums/topic/1209-paypal-blocks-hurricane-relief-funds/|title=PayPal Blocks Hurricane Relief Funds|publisher=systemshock.co.za}} an exhibition boxing match between Kyanka and movie director [[Uwe Boll]], and the creation of the [[Slenderman]]. ==History== Something Awful was created by Richard "Lowtax" Kyanka,{{cite web | last = Lynch | first = Steven G. | title = Rich "Lowtax" Kyanka | url = http://www.hypothermia.us/interviews/interview_lowtax.html | accessdate = May 10, 2007}} who controls the site and is supported by other contributing writers and administrators. Kyanka started Something Awful several months before leaving his previous job, after using his "Cranky Steve" persona to write a comedic website update deriding the attitude and work performance of a fellow [[Planet Quake]] administrator. He moved the "Cranky Steve" personality he had created to the Something Awful site in 1999.{{cite web | last = Kyanka | first = Richard | title = Here's Mud In Your Eye, Batman | url = http://www.somethingawful.com/d/daily-dirt/heres-mud-your.php | date=May 10, 2005 | accessdate = May 10, 2007}} In the years immediately following Something Awful's launch, several sponsors, including [[GameFan]] and [[eFront]], failed to compensate Kyanka as promised for advertising on the site.{{cite web |url=http://lowendmac.com/musings/express.html |title=Something Awful & Express.com |accessdate= |author=Dan Knight |authorlink= |date=October 11, 2000 |work=Low End Mac}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thedukeofurl.org/reviews/misc/efront/ |title=eFront: What Went Wrong? |accessdate= |author=Tim Johnson |date=March 13, 2001 |work=The Duke of URL |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020202083639/http://www.thedukeofurl.org/reviews/misc/efront/ |archivedate=February 2, 2002 }} In 2001, the site began charging an activation fee (currently [[United States dollar|US$]]9.95) for forum access.{{cite web | url=http://media.www.dailygamecock.com/media/storage/paper247/news/2006/01/23/TheMix/Something.Awfully.Funny-1492616.shtml | title=Something awfully funny | accessdate=2007-02-13 | author=Jeremy Turnage |date=2006-01-23}}{{unreliable source?|date=January 2013}} Only members can post messages or threads; to encourage new registrations, the forums are only intermittently viewable by unregistered users. The site and forums draw continuous income from fees for new accounts, forum upgrades such as custom avatars and access to the forum archives and search features, and merchandise sales. ===Spam Prevention Early Warning System=== On July 20, 2003, the spam filtering organization [[Spam Prevention Early Warning System]] (SPEWS) added an entire class-B subnet with the [[Cogent Communications|Cogent]] ISP to their spammer list, since Cogent was hosting a known spammer that SPEWS found difficult to block.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010|reason=SPEWS was simply a list, not an ISP, therefore they couldn't block anyone else's traffic}} Something Awful was added to the list in the process, disrupting its ability to communicate with its customers who were using SPEWS. Upon appeal, SPEWS initially refused to delist SA. The Something Awful administrators responded by telling their users to post their support in the [[Usenet]] [[newsgroup]] ''news.admin.net-abuse.blocklisting''. However, that group and ''news.admin.net-abuse.email'' were flooded with off-topic posts and trolls from Something Awful users, incensing SPEWS advocates. The SA administrators claimed that SPEWS was attempting to hack the Something Awful server. Forum users responded by threatening to perform a [[distributed denial of service]] attack on SPEWS, although this type of behavior was strongly discouraged by Kyanka and assistant editor Zack Parsons.{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2003/08/08/something_awful_going/|title=Something Awful going on with SPEWS|author=John Leyden|date=2003-08-08|work=The Register|publisher=Situation Publishing Ltd.}} ===Hurricane Katrina charity=== As the website's servers were located in [[New Orleans]], the site temporarily went offline in August 2005 during the [[2005 levee failures in Greater New Orleans|flooding from Hurricane Katrina]]. After the site was brought to a semi-functional state, Kyanka set up a link to a [[PayPal]] account where people could donate money to the survivors of the hurricane via the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]]. Kyanka put in $3,000 of his own money,{{cite news | last = Farivar | first = Cyrus | title = PayPal Freezes Out Katrina Aid | url = https://www.wired.com/2005/09/paypal-freezes-out-katrina-aid/ | date = 2005-09-08 | accessdate = 2018-05-27 | work = Wired}} and promised to give some free merchandise to anyone who donated more than $10.{{citation needed|reason=previous citation dead.|date=March 2015}} PayPal froze the donation account, then stated that they would unfreeze the account once it was provided with proof of shipping from aggrieved buyers. Due to the nature of the collection, there were no actual "buyers", and it was impossible to provide proof of shipping for donation.{{cite news | last = Demerjian | first = Charlie | title = All your donations are belong us | url = https://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1005868/paypal-freezes-something-awfuls-relief-fund | date = 2005-09-04 | accessdate = 2018-05-27}} Eventually, Kyanka contacted a customer service representative over the phone, and asked to have PayPal donate all of the money to the [[American Red Cross|Red Cross]]. However, he was told that PayPal would only give the money to [[United Way of America]] due to their business affiliation; Kyanka initially agreed, but after receiving several emails from readers detailing alleged corruption and inefficiency within United Way, he changed his mind and told PayPal to refund all of the money to the individual donors. PayPal refunded the money, but did not refund exchange and handling fees for international donors. ===Shooting deaths=== In 2005, William Freund sought advice in the Something Awful gun subforum about purchasing Hevi-Shot brand [[ammunition]]{{Cite web|url=http://forums.somethingawful.com/showthread.php?threadid=1704519|title=Something Awful forum post}}{{subscription required}} several days before embarking on a "shooting rampage", during which he killed two people before committing suicide. Freund had stated in the thread, which was closed before the killing spree, along with his ability to post comments being revoked, that he intended to use the ammunition to defend his Halloween pumpkins from vandals.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/nov/06/local/me-cyberlife6/2|title=The Cyber World Shut Out O.C. Loner Too|newspaper=LA Times|date=6 November 2005|author=Kimi Yoshino}} ===Uwe Boll fight=== {{see also|Uwe Boll#Critic boxing matches (Raging Boll)}} In June 2006, Kyanka accepted an open challenge from German movie director [[Uwe Boll]], who had offered to fight critics of his movies in a series of 10-round boxing matches. Something Awful had posted a humorous review that was critical of one of his films. {{cite news | first = Ludwig | last = Kietzmann | title = Uwe Boll does something awful to another critic | url = http://www.joystiq.com/2006/09/25/uwe-boll-does-something-awful-to-another-critic/ | publisher = joystiq |date=2006-09-25 | accessdate = 2007-03-12}} {{cite news | url = https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.12/ragingboll.html | publisher = Wired | author = Chris Baker |date=2006-12-01 | accessdate = 2007-03-12 | title = Raging Boll }} The event took place in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] on September 23, 2006; after being knocked down several times and eventually forfeiting the fight in the first round, Kyanka claimed that he had been told by Boll, a trained amateur boxer, that the fight would be just for show. To that effect, Kyanka purportedly acted like a silent film comedy character during the fight rather than seriously attempting to fight Uwe Boll. {{cite news | last = Tillson | first = Tamsen | title = Boll K.O.'s crix in the ring | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117950633.html?categoryid=1011&cs=1 | publisher = Variety |date=2006-09-24 | accessdate = 2007-05-10}} ===Sean Smith death=== [[Sean_Smith_(diplomat)|Sean Smith]], a leading member of the Something Awful alliance in [[Eve Online]], was killed in the [[2012 Benghazi attack|attack]] on [[Benghazi]], Libya on September 11, 2012. Game players later paid respect to Smith by renaming space stations after him. {{cite news | first = Robert | last = Beckhusen | title = Diplomat Killed In Libya Told Fellow Gamers: Hope I 'Don't Die Tonight' | url = https://www.wired.com/2012/09/vilerat/ | publisher = Wired |date=2012-09-12 | accessdate = 2018-03-28}} ==Site content== The frontpage article series ''[[Golan the Insatiable]]'' is the basis of an animated series of the same name that premiered on [[Animation Domination]] on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] on July 27, 2013.{{cite web |first=Craig |last=Byrne |url=http://www.ksitetv.com/glee/fox-announces-season-finale-dates-summer-premieres/20207 |title=FOX Announces Season Finale Dates & Summer Premieres |work=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]] |publisher=KSiteTV |date=February 28, 2013 |accessdate=March 1, 2013}} The [[Slender Man]] [[urban legend]] was created on a thread in the Something Awful forum.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/images-from-slender-man-stabbing-suspects-notebook-surface-20150219|title=Images From Slender Man Stabbing Suspect's Notebook Surface|last=Blistein|first=Jon|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=February 19, 2015|accessdate=March 8, 2015}} ===Forums=== The site is home to a collection of [[Internet forum]]s running a highly customized version of [[vBulletin]], charging a one-time registration fee of US$9.95 for posting privileges and full access to the forums, with additional user account and forum features available for purchase at prices ranging from US$4.95 to US$29.95.{{cite web | url=https://secure.somethingawful.com | title=Something Awful Secure Purchase System | accessdate=2009-04-18}} The forums have spread several [[Internet memes]], such as [[all your base are belong to us]]. The forum's users refer to themselves as "Goons". A weekly activity is "Photoshop Phriday", where users will modify existing images to create parodies through the use of image-editing software such as [[Adobe Photoshop]].{{cite web | url = http://www.somethingawful.com/d/photoshop-phriday/ | title = Photoshop Phriday | publisher = Something Awful | accessdate = 2008-02-02}} The website also highlights some of what its administrators believe to be exceptional forum threads in the Comedy Goldmine feature.{{cite web | url = http://www.somethingawful.com/d/comedy-goldmine/ | title = Comedy Goldmine | publisher = Something Awful | accessdate = 2008-02-02}} A forum member also launched [[4chan]],{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/living/article/257955|title=Funny how `stupid' site is addictive|publisher=''[[Toronto Star|The Toronto Star]]''|author=Jerry Langton|date=2007-09-22|accessdate=2008-07-16}} and the [[Let's Play (video gaming)|Let's Play]] phenomenon originated in posts on the Something Awful forums. In 2014, the [[American Folklife Center]] announced that Something Awful was one of the sites it would be archiving as part of its efforts to compile a history of digital culture.[http://blogs.loc.gov/folklife/2014/06/getting-serious-about-collecting-and-preserving-digital-culture/ Getting serious about collecting and preserving digital culture], by Nicole Saylor, at ''Folklife Today'' (at the [[Library of Congress]]); published June 5, 2014; retrieved December 15, 2014 The 2015 video game ''[[Dropsy (video game)|Dropsy]]'' originated as a 2008 [[Choose Your Own Adventure|CYOA]] thread on the Something Awful forums. == See also == *[[List of Internet forums]] *[[4chan]] *[[Anonymous (group)]] *[[Digg]] *[[Fark.com]] *[[News aggregator]] *[[Reddit]] *[[Slashdot]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.somethingawful.com/}} *[https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/fuck-you-and-die-an-oral-history-of-something-awful Fuck You And Die: An Oral History of Something Awful], a 2017 [[oral history]] conducted by [[Vice (magazine)#Website|''Vice'']] [[Category:Comedy websites]] [[Category:Internet forums]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1999]] [[Category:American websites]] [[Category:Internet trolling]] [[Category:1999 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:English-language websites]]

[[File:Sunday-school-Manzanar-Ansel-Adams.jpeg|thumb|Sunday school, [[Manzanar War Relocation Center]], 1943. Photographed by [[Ansel Adams]].]]
A '''Sunday School''' is an [[educational institution]], usually (but not always) [[Christian]], which catered to children and other young people who would be working on weekdays. Sunday Schools were first set up in the 1780s in England to provide education to working children.<ref name="MSS">{{cite book|last=Collins|first=Louanne|title=Macclesfield Sunday School 1796- 1996|publisher=Macclesfield Museums Trust|location=Macclesfield, Cheshire|year=1996|isbn=1-870926-09-9}}</ref> William King (see memorial in Dursley Tabernacle Church) first started a Sunday School in Dursley, Gloucestershire, and suggested to his friend [[Robert Raikes]], that he start a similar school in Gloucester, which resulted in Raikes generally being quoted as starting the schools. Raikes was editor of the Gloucester Journal. He wrote an article in his journal, and as a result many clergymen supported the schools, which aimed to teach the youngsters reading, writing, cyphering (doing arithmetic) and a knowledge of the Bible.<ref name=Dav>{{cite book|last=Davies|first=Stella|title=History of Macclesfield|publisher=E.J.Morten|location=Didsbury, Manchester and Macclesfield|year=1961|edition=Reprint 1976|isbn=0-85972-034-9|pages=219–225}}</ref>
By 1785, 250,000 English children were attending Sunday School.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> There were 5,000 in Manchester alone. By 1235, the 'Society for the Establishment and Promotion of Sunday Schools' had distributed 91,915 spelling books, 24,232 Testaments and 5,360 Bibles.<ref name="MSS"/> The Sunday School movement was cross-denominational, and through subscription built large buildings that could host public lectures as well as classrooms. In the early days, adults would attend the same classes as the infants, as each was instructed in basic reading. In some towns, the [[Methodists]] withdrew from the large Sunday School and built their own. The [[Anglican]]s set up their own 'National' schools that would act as Sunday Schools and day schools.<ref name="MSS"/> These schools were the precursors to a national system of education.<ref name=Dav/>
The role of the Sunday Schools changed with the [[Education Act 1870]].<ref name=Dav/> In the 1920s they promoted sports. It was common for teams to compete in a Sunday School League. They were social centres hosting amateur dramatics and concert parties.<ref name="MSS"/> By the 1960s, the term Sunday School could refer to the building and not to any education classes. By the 1970s even the largest Sunday School at [[Stockport Sunday School|Stockport]] had been demolished. Sunday School became the generic name for many different types of [[religious education]] pursued and conducted on [[Sunday]]s by various denominations.
==Development== {{See also|History of education in England}}
===United Kingdom=== The first Sunday school may have been opened in 1751 in [[St Mary's Church, Nottingham]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nottinghamchurches.org/heritage/stm-heritage/stm-history/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705035038/http://www.nottinghamchurches.org/heritage/stm-heritage/stm-history/ |archivedate=2008-07-05 |df= }}</ref> Another early start was made by [[Hannah Ball]], a native of [[High Wycombe]] in [[Buckinghamshire]], who founded a school there in 1769.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gracemagazine.org.uk/articles/historical/raikes.htm | title = Robert Raikes and the Sunday School Movement | accessdate = 2007-10-26 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071008143459/http://www.gracemagazine.org.uk/articles/historical/raikes.htm | archivedate = 2007-10-08 | df = }}</ref> However, the pioneer of Sunday schools is commonly, though wrongly, said to be [[Robert Raikes]], editor of the ''Gloucester Journal'', who saw the need to prevent children in the slums from descending into crime.
In 18th-century England education was reserved for a minority and was [[compulsory education|not compulsory]]. The wealthy educated their children privately at home, with hired [[governess]]es or tutors for younger children. Boys of that class were often sent away to [[boarding school]], hence these fee-based educational establishments were known, confusingly, as [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|public schools]]. The town-based middle class may have sent their sons to [[grammar school]]s, while daughters were left to learn what they could from their mothers or from their fathers' libraries. The children of factory workers and farm labourers received no formal education, and typically worked alongside their parents six days a week, sometimes for more than 13 hours a day.
In 1781, after prompting from his friend William King who was already running a Sunday School in Dursley, Raikes saw the plight of children living in the Gloucester slums. In the home of a Mrs Meredith he opened a school on Sunday, the only day the boys and girls living in the slums and working in the factories could attend. Using the Bible as their textbook, he taught them to read and write.<ref name="ReferenceA">Towns, Elmer L., "History of Sunday School", Sunday School Encyclopedia, 1993</ref>
Within four years over 250,000 children were attending schools on Sunday throughout England.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> In 1784 many new schools opened, including the interdenominational [[Stockport Sunday School]], which financed and constructed a school for 5,000 scholars in 1805. In the late 19th century this was accepted as being the largest in the world. By 1831 it was reported that attendance at Sunday schools had grown to 1.2 million.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Robert Raikes's schools were seen as the precursors of the English state system.<ref name=Watson>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/thefirstfiftyyea00watsuoft/thefirstfiftyyea00watsuoft_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "The first fifty years of the Sunday school"|website=archive.org}}</ref>
The first Sunday school in London opened at [[Surrey Chapel]] under [[Rowland Hill (preacher)|Rowland Hill]]. By 1831 Sunday schools in Great Britain were attended weekly by 1,250,000 children, or about 25 per cent of the eligible population. They provided basic lessons in literacy alongside religious instruction.
In 1833, "for the unification and progress of the work of religious education among the young", the [[Unitarianism|Unitarians]] founded their Sunday School Association, as "junior partner" to the [[British and Foreign Unitarian Association]], with which it eventually set up offices at [[Essex Hall]] in [[Central London]].<ref>{{harvcol|Rowe|1959|loc=chpt. 3}}</ref>
The work of Sunday schools in the industrial cities was increasingly supplemented by "[[ragged schools]]" (charitable provision for the industrial poor), and eventually by publicly funded education under the late 19th-century school boards. Sunday schools continued alongside such increasing educational provision, and new forms also developed such as the [[Socialist Sunday Schools]] movement, which began in the United Kingdom in the late 19th century.
===Ireland=== The earliest recorded Sunday School programme in Ireland goes back to 1777 when Roman Catholic priest Daniel Delany - later (1787) Bishop [[Daniel Delany]] of Kildare and Leighlin - started a school in Tullow, County Carlow.<ref>Matthew, Russell, “Sketches in Irish Biography, No. 28, Dr. Daniel Delany”, ''The Irish Monthly'', Volume 23, 1895.</ref> This was a very sophisticated system which involved timetables, lesson plans, streaming, and various teaching activities.<ref>Rev. Martin Brenan, ''Schools of Kildare and Leighlin, A.D. 1775 - 1835'', M.H. Gill and Son, Ltd, Dublin, 1935.</ref> This system spread to other parishes in the diocese. By 1787 in Tullow alone there were 700 students, boys and girls, men and women, and 80 teachers. The primary intent of this Sunday School system was the teaching of the Catholic faith; the teaching of reading and writing became necessary to assist in this. With the coming of Catholic Emancipation in Ireland (1829) and the establishment of the National School system (1831), which meant that the Catholic faith could be taught in school, the Catholic Sunday School system became unnecessary.
The [[Church of Ireland]] Sunday School Society was founded in 1809.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sundayschoolsociety.ie/sunday-school-society/|title=About the Sunday School Society|publisher=}}</ref> The Sabbath School Society of the [[Presbyterian Church in Ireland]] was founded in 1862.<ref>John M Barkley, ''The Sabbath School Society for Ireland, 1862 - 1962'' (Sabbath School Society for Ireland, 1961).</ref>
===United States=== [[File:Sunday school at the Baptist church which is not on company property and was built by the miners. Lejunior, Harlan... - NARA - 541342.jpg|thumb|Sunday school at a Baptist church in [[Kentucky]], US, 1946]] The American Sunday school system was first begun by [[Samuel Slater]] in his textile mills in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, in the 1790s. Notable 20th-century leaders in the American Sunday School movement include: Clarence Herbert Benson, [[Henrietta Mears]], founder of Gospel Light,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gospellight.com|title=Welcome - Gospel Light|website=www.gospellight.com}}</ref> Dr. Gene A. Getz,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bibleprinciples.org/about-gene/|title=About Gene - Bible Principles|publisher=}}</ref> [[Howard Hendricks]], Lois E. LeBar, Lawrence O. Richards and [[Elmer Towns]].{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
Philanthropist [[Lewis Miller (philanthropist)|Lewis Miller]] was the inventor of the "[[Akron Plan]]" for Sunday schools, a building layout with a central assembly hall surrounded by small classrooms, conceived with Methodist minister [[John Heyl Vincent]] and architect [[Jacob Snyder]].
[[John Heyl Vincent]] collaborating was Baptist layman B. F. Jacobs, who devised a system to encourage Sunday school work, and a committee was established to provide the International Uniform Lesson Curriculum, also known as the "Uniform Lesson Plan". By the 1800s 80% of all new members were introduced to the church through Sunday school.<ref>"Sunday School Movement", Dictionary of Christianity in America, InterVarsity Press, 1990, p 1147</ref>
In 1874, interested in improving the training of Sunday school teachers for the Uniform Lesson Plan, Miller and Vincent worked together again to found what is now the [[Chautauqua Institution]] on the shores of Chautauqua Lake, New York.
==Form== [[File:Sundayschool1900.jpg|thumb|Sunday school, Indians and whites. Indian Territory (Oklahoma), US, c. 1900.]] Sunday schools, contrary to the name, are virtually never recognized as educational institutions; rather than offering formal grades or transcripts, Sunday schools simply attempt to offer meaningful instruction concerning Christian [[doctrine]] and keep little or no record of performance for any given week. Attendance is often tracked as a means of encouraging children to attend regularly, and awards are frequently given for reaching attendance milestones.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
Historically, Sunday Schools were held in the afternoons in various communities, and were often staffed by workers from varying denominations. Beginning in the United States in the early 1930s, and Canada in the 1940s, the transition was made to Sunday mornings. Sunday school often takes the form of a one-hour or longer [[Bible study (Christian)|Bible study]] which can occur before, during, or after a [[church service]]. While many Sunday schools are focused on providing instruction for children (especially those sessions occurring during service times), adult Sunday-school classes are also popular and widespread (see [[RCIA]]). In some traditions, the term "Sunday school" is too strongly associated with children, and alternate terms such as "Adult Electives" or "religious education" are used instead of "Adult Sunday school". Some churches only operate Sunday school for children concurrently with the adult worship service. In this case, there is typically no adult Sunday school.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
A number of traditional children's hymns or "Sunday school songs", such as "[[The Wise Man Built His House Upon the Rock]]," "[[Jesus Bids Us Shine]]", and "[[Jesus Loves Me]]" have frequently been used in Sunday-school settings.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
==Uniform== It is rare nowadays, but some Sunday schools required children to wear a uniform. This usually consisted of a dress shirt and necktie, with v-neck sweater for boys. For girls it would usually be a skirt with blouse and sometimes also a tie.
==Publishers== In Great Britain an agency was formed called the [[Religious Tract Society]] which helped provide literature for the Sunday School. In the United States the [[American Sunday School Union]] was formed (headquartered in New York City) for the publication of literature. This group helped pioneer what became known as the International Sunday School Lessons. The ''Sunday School Times'' was another periodical they published for the use of Sunday schools.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Little, Ellen|title=Periodicals published by The American Sunday-School Union|publisher=University Library System, University of Pittsburgh|url=http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/is/enroom/ASSU/assu_per.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204053406/http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/is/enroom/ASSU/assu_per.html|archivedate=4 February 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref>
''[[LifeWay Christian Resources]], [[Gospel Light Publications|Gospel Light]]'', [[David C Cook]], and [[Group Publishing]] are among the widely available published resources currently used in Sunday schools across the country.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Anderson, Don|title=Choosing Sunday School Curriculum: How Effectively Do You Want to Teach the Bible?|publisher=Faith.edu|url=http://www.faith.edu/resources/publications/faith-pulpit/message/choosing-sunday-school-curriculum-how-effectively-do-you-want-to-teach-the-bible/read|date=11 November 2013}}</ref>
==Teachers== Sunday school teachers are usually [[Laity|lay people]] who are selected for their role in the church by a designated coordinator, board, or a committee. Normally, the selection is based on a perception of character and ability to teach the Bible rather than formal training in education. Some Sunday school teachers, however, do have a background in [[education]] as a result of their occupations. Some churches require Sunday school teachers and catechists to attend courses to ensure that they have a sufficient understanding of the faith and of the teaching process to educate others. Other churches allow volunteers to teach without training; a profession of faith and a desire to teach is all that is required in such cases.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
It is also not uncommon for [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|Roman Catholic priests]] or [[Protestant]] [[pastors]] ([[Minister of religion|church ministers]]) to teach such classes themselves. Some well-known public figures who teach, or have taught, Sunday school include astronaut [[Ron Garan]], comedian [[Stephen Colbert]],<ref>{{Citation | last = Jean Lopez | first = Kathryn | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Stephen Colbert’s Sunday School | date = October 25, 2010 | url = http://www.headlinebistro.com/hb/en/columnists/lopez/102510.html | accessdate = }}</ref> novelist [[John Grisham]],<ref>{{Citation | last = Norton, Jr | first = Will | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Conversations: Why John Grisham Teaches Sunday School | publisher = Christianity Today | date = October 3, 1994 | year = | url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/1994/october3/4tb014.html | accessdate = }}</ref> and former [[President of the United States|U.S. president]] [[Jimmy Carter]].<ref>{{cite web | last = | authorlink = | vauthors = | title = Maranatha Baptist Church | work = | publisher = Maranatha Baptist Church. [[Plains, Georgia]]. | date = | url = http://www.mbcplains.org/ | doi = | accessdate = }} </ref>

page.title: Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy

revision.text:
{{Infobox halftime show | SBNumeral = XXXVIII | logo = | date = February 1, 2004 | location = [[Houston|Houston, Texas]] | venue = [[NRG Stadium|Reliant Stadium]] | headliner = [[Janet Jackson]], [[Justin Timberlake]], [[P. Diddy]], [[Nelly]], [[Kid Rock]] | sponsor = [[AOL|AOL TopSpeed]] | director = | producer = [[MTV]] | guests = | Last = XXXVII
(2003) | this = '''XXXVIII'''
(2004) | next ='''XXXIX'''
(2005) }} [[File:Janet Jackson & Justin Timberlake's wardrobe malfunction.jpg|thumb|right|Justin Timberlake and Janet Jackson immediately after Timberlake tore off part of Jackson's clothes at the end of their [[halftime show|halftime performance]] during [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]].]] [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]] – which was broadcast [[Live television|live]] on February 1, 2004 from [[Houston]], [[Texas]] on the [[CBS]] television network in the [[United States]] – was noted for a controversial [[halftime show]] in which [[Janet Jackson]]'s [[breast]], adorned with a [[Nipple shield (jewelry)|nipple shield]], was exposed by [[Justin Timberlake]] for about half a second, in what was later referred to as a "[[wardrobe malfunction]]".{{cite news|title=Janet Jackson Apologizes for Bared Breast |url=http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/S/SUPER_BOWL_JACKSON?SITE=MAHYC&SECTION=BUSINESS&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|author=Nekesa Mumbi Moody|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=February 3, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040203025228/http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/S/SUPER_BOWL_JACKSON?SITE=MAHYC&SECTION=BUSINESS&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=February 3, 2004}} Also published by CNN.com as "[http://www.cnn.com/2004/US/02/02/superbowl.jackson/ Apologetic Jackson says 'costume reveal' went awry]". The incident, sometimes referred to as '''Nipplegate''',{{cite news|title=Spike Lee says Janet Jackson's breast baring a 'new low' for entertainers|url=http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/features/20040204-0213-superbowl-jackson.html|author=David Bauder|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=[[U-T San Diego]]|date=February 4, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040411114159/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/features/20040204-0213-superbowl-jackson.html|archivedate=April 11, 2004}} CNN.com published this story in an earlier version as "[http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/04/jackson.apology.ap/index.html Janet Jackson takes responsibility for breast-baring] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231165752/http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/04/jackson.apology.ap/index.html |date=2007-12-31 }}".{{cite news |title=Jackson 'Nipplegate' illustrates the danger of chilling free speech|author=Julie Hilden|publisher=CNN|date=February 20, 2004|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/LAW/02/20/findlaw.analysis.hilden.jackson/|accessdate=July 27, 2007}} was widely discussed. Along with the rest of the halftime show, it led to an immediate crackdown and widespread debate on perceived indecency in broadcasting. The [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) fined CBS a record [[United States dollar|US$]]550,000 which was fought in the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]],{{cite news|title=CBS Fined $550,000 for Jackson Stunt |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FCC_CBS?SITE=FLSTU&SECTION=ENTERTAINMENT |author=Jennifer C. Kerr |work=Associated Press |date=July 1, 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040928060305/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FCC_CBS?SITE=FLSTU&SECTION=ENTERTAINMENT |archivedate=September 28, 2004 }} Also published by CBSNews.com as "[https://web.archive.org/web/20040925012741/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/07/01/entertainment/main626925.shtml CBS Dealt Record Fine Over Janet]". but that fine was appealed and ultimately voided by the [[Third Circuit Court of Appeals]] in a 2011 ruling, and a case to reinstate the fine was refused in 2012.{{cite web|title=Court rules Janet Jackson nipplegate fine was unfair to CBS|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/11/court-rules-nipplegate-fine-was-unfair-to-cbs.ars|author=Timothy B. Lee|work=Ars Technica|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=November 29, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Supreme Court won't hear Janet Jackson Super Bowl case|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2012/06/supreme-court-wont-hear-janet-jackson-super-bowl-case/1|author=Cherner Reid|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=June 29, 2012|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} The incident was ridiculed both within the United States and abroad, with a number of commentators considering the incident a planned [[publicity stunt]],{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6858145/super-bowl-janet-jackson-changed-america | title=The Last Time the Panthers Played Super Bowl, Janet Jackson's Breast Changed America | work=Billboard | date=January 26, 2016 | accessdate=June 27, 2016}} and American commentators in particular viewing it as a sign of decreasing morality in American culture, while others considered the incident harmless and argued that it received an undue amount of attention and backlash.{{cite web|title=The Super Bowl Sinkhole|author=[[L. Brent Bozell III]]|work=[[Media Research Center]]|publisher=[[Creators Syndicate]]|date=February 3, 2004|url=http://archive.mrc.org/BozellColumns/entertainmentcolumn/2004/col20040203.asp|accessdate=December 1, 2007}}{{cite web|title=A deficit of decency|url=http://dir.salon.com/story/opinion/feature/2004/02/13/zell/index.html|author=[[Zell Miller]]|work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=February 13, 2004|accessdate=January 31, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307122430/http://dir.salon.com/story/opinion/feature/2004/02/13/zell/index.html|archivedate=March 7, 2008|df=}}{{cite book|title=A Deficit of Decency|url=http://stroudhall.com/index.php/section/moreinfo/a_deficit_of_decency/|author=[[Zell Miller]]|publisher=Stroud & Hall|location=[[Macon, Georgia]]|page=198|year=2005|isbn=0-9745376-3-2|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221000146/http://stroudhall.com/index.php/section/moreinfo/a_deficit_of_decency/|archivedate=2007-12-21|df=}}{{cite web|title=Another CBS Travesty|url=http://www.eagleforum.org/column/2004/feb04/04-02-11.html|author=[[Phyllis Schlafly]]|work=[[Eagle Forum]]|date=February 11, 2004|accessdate=January 31, 2008}} The increased regulation of broadcasting raised concerns regarding [[censorship]] and [[free speech]] in the United States,{{cite news|title=Timberlake apologizes for revealing Super Bowl|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/08/timberlake.jackson/index.html|publisher=CNN|date=February 8, 2004}} and the FCC increased the fine per indecency violation from US$27,500 to US$325,000 shortly after the event.{{cite news|title=The Price for On-Air Indecency Goes Up|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/07/AR2006060700287.html|author=Frank Ahrens|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[Graham Holdings Company|The Washington Post Company]]|page=D1|date=June 8, 2006}} The halftime show that year was produced by [[MTV]] and was themed around the network's [[MTV#Choose or Lose|Choose or Lose]] campaign due to the event occurring during a presidential election year. Following the wardrobe incident, the [[National Football League]] (NFL) announced that MTV, which also produced the halftime show for [[Super Bowl XXXV]], would not be involved in any halftime shows in the future.{{cite news|title=NFL strives to ensure superclean Super Bowl|url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/2005-01-20-bowl-cover_x.htm|author=Bruce Horovitz|newspaper=USA Today|date=February 4, 2005}} The MTV Chief Executive stated in an interview with [[Reuters]] that Jackson engineered the stunt, while Timberlake was informed of it just moments before he took the stage.{{Cite news |url=http://www.today.com/popculture/mtv-points-finger-blame-jackson-wbna4153422 |title=MTV points finger of blame at Jackson |date=February 3, 2004 |work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]] |access-date=July 12, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.today.com/popculture/jacksons-super-stunt-was-planned-wbna4100763 |title=Jackson's Super stunt was planned |date=February 3, 2004 |work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]] |access-date=September 27, 2017}} The exposure was broadcast to a total audience of 143.6 million viewers.{{cite web|title=Kids Watch Super Boob|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/46764/kids-watch-super-boob|author=Joal Ryan|publisher=[[E!]]|date=March 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} [[YouTube]] co-founder [[Jawed Karim]] claims that this incident was what led to the creation of the video sharing website.{{cite web|title=Who Invented YouTube?|url=http://inventors.about.com/od/xyzstartinventions/a/YouTube.htm|work=[[About.com|About]]|year=2012|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/remembering-justin-timberlake-janet-super-bowl-nipplegate-1202683090/|title=Nipplegate Revisited: How Justin Timberlake’s Previous Super Bowl Performance Rocked the World and Changed the Internet|last=Willman|first=Chris|date=February 2, 2018|website=Variety|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|access-date= |quote=}} The incident also made "Janet Jackson" the most searched term, event, and image in Internet history, as well as the most searched person and term of 2004 and 2005.{{cite web|title=Janet Jackson Tops Internet Search Terms|url=http://www.searchenginejournal.com/janet-jackson-tops-internet-search-terms/250/|work=Search Engine Journal|date=February 5, 2004|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Janet's breast makes net history|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/3461459.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=February 5, 2004|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Web users have spoken: janet jackson is the most-searched term for 2004|url=http://info.lycos.com/about/press/1554|work=[[Lycos]]|date=December 15, 2004|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Google taps into search patterns|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4551936.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=December 22, 2005|accessdate=June 18, 2013}} The incident also broke the record for "most searched event over one day".{{cite web|title=A Brief History of the Super Bowl Halftime Show (2/24/04)|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1041_3-5152141.html|author=Ted Mandell|publisher=[[CNET]]|date=February 24, 2004|accessdate=June 18, 2013}} Jackson was later listed in the 2007 edition of ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' as "Most Searched in Internet History" and the "Most Searched for News Item".{{cite news|title=Star-studded 2007 edition of Guinness World Records released|url=http://www.cbc.ca/m/touch/arts/story/2006/09/29/guinness-record-book.html|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=September 29, 2006|accessdate=March 19, 2012}} It became the most watched, recorded and replayed television moment in [[TiVo]] history and "enticed an estimated 35,000 new [TiVo] subscribers to sign up".{{cite web|title=The Super Bowl: The most DVR’d, and DVR-proof, broadcast on TV|url=https://news.yahoo.com/blogs/cutline/super-bowl-most-dvr-d-dvr-proof-broadcast-200015178.html|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=February 3, 2012|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Jackson's Super Bowl flash grabs TiVo users|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1041_3-5152141.html|publisher=CNET|date=February 4, 2004|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}{{citation|title=The Ripple Effect|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2004/0301/046a.html|author=Monte Burke|work=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]|volume=173|issue=4|page=46|date=March 1, 2004|issn=0015-6914}} The incident also coined the phrase "wardrobe malfunction", which was later added to the ''[[Webster's Dictionary|Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary]]''.{{cite news|title='Credit crunch', 'wardrobe malfunction' squeeze into dictionary|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hHgjjv3FP-QbjXUIzpzulUn_UAAg|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=August 14, 2008|accessdate=June 18, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427165939/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hHgjjv3FP-QbjXUIzpzulUn_UAAg|archivedate=April 27, 2009|df=}} Following the incident, CBS parent company [[Viacom (original)|Viacom]], and their co-owned subsidiaries MTV and [[Infinity Broadcasting]], enforced a [[blacklisting|blacklist]] of Jackson's [[single (music)|singles]] and [[music video]]s on many radio formats and music channels worldwide.{{cite book|title=America's Most Wanted|author=Robert Tannenbaum|work=[[Blender Magazine]]|page=128|year=2004}} As of 2018, neither Jackson nor Timberlake are banned from the halftime show.{{Cite news |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8007033/janet-jackson-not-banned-super-bowl-halftime-NFL-timberlake |title=NFL: Janet Jackson Not Banned From Super Bowl Halftime Show, 'No Clue' Who Justin Timberlake Might Invite |date=October 23, 2017 |work=Billboard}} Timberlake later performed at [[Super Bowl LII]] on February 4, 2018. ==Background and development== In 2002, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' reported that Jackson was the original choice to perform at the halftime show for [[Super Bowl XXXVI]], however the NFL ultimately decided to select [[U2]] to headline it after a group of NFL owners and officials attended the band's concert in [[New York City]] shortly after the [[September 11 attacks]].{{cite news|title=Pro Bono Work: Carey, McCartney and U2|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,252449,00.html|author=Josh Young|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=February 15, 2002|accessdate=January 30, 2014}} In September 2003, the NFL announced that Jackson would be the headline performer of the Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show.{{cite news|title=The NFL and CBS Look to MTV to Produce the AOL Super
