Bowl XXXVIII Halftime Show|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-nfl-and-cbs-look-to-mtv-to-produce-the-aol-super-bowl-xxxviii-halftime-show-73262057.html|agency=[[PR Newswire]]|date=September 12, 2003|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Because the event was occurring during [[United States presidential election, 2004|an election year]], MTV decided that the show's theme would heavily focus on the network's "[[MTV#Choose or Lose|Choose or Lose]]" campaign, which encouraged younger viewers to be politically active and register to vote.{{Harvard citation no brackets|Lane|2006|pp=25}} Prior to the incident, Timberlake had attended Jackson's ''[[Rhythm Nation Tour]]'' as an [[adolescence|adolescent]], and Jackson's energetic dance routines and daring performing style made a deep impression on him.{{cite book|title=Justin: The Unauthorized Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cki-FYnGCu8C&pg=PA184|author=Sean Smith|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|page=184|year=2005}} While Timberlake was a member of pop group [['N Sync]], Jackson selected the [[boy band]] as the opening act for many dates of her blockbuster ''[[Velvet Rope Tour|Velvet Rope World Tour]]'', which helped promote and introduce the then-relatively unknown group and Timberlake to the public worldwide.{{cite web|title=Janet Extends Velvet Rope|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1430407/janet-extends-velvet-rope.jhtml|publisher=[[MTV News]]|date=August 9, 1998|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Timberlake said he was "psyched" and later described the experience as "fulfilling".{{cite web|title=*N Sync Me: Transcript of chat with Justin|url=http://nsyncme.tripod.com/yahoojustin2.html|publisher=Tripod|date=March 18, 1999|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} While on the tour, Jackson further promoted the group by performing with 'N Sync on several dates, including joining the group for a live [[a cappella]] duet of [[Stevie Wonder]]'s "[[Overjoyed (Stevie Wonder song)|Overjoyed]]", which a biography stated was a "highlight" moment for Timberlake which "gave Justin a chance to show his family and friends how far he had come".{{cite book|title=Justin: The Unauthorized Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cki-FYnGCu8C&pg=PA112|author=Sean Smith|publisher=Simon & Schuster|page=112|date=January 11, 2005|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Following the tour, Timberlake and Jackson became "good friends", with Jackson also praising Timberlake.{{cite web|title=Justin: The Unauthorized Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cki-FYnGCu8C&pg=PA189|author=Sean Smith|work=Simon & Schuster|date=January 11, 2005|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Timberlake recreated Jackson's "[[That's the Way Love Goes (Janet Jackson song)|That's the Way Love Goes]]" video with 'N Sync and was inspired by Jackson's performing style.{{cite web|title=Fear of a Black Titty|url=http://www.laweekly.com/2004-05-06/music/fear-of-a-black-titty/|author=Ernest Hardy|work=[[LA Weekly]]|page=1|date=June 5, 2004|accessdate=December 25, 2013| archivedate=May 4, 2016 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160504022131/http://www.laweekly.com/music/fear-of-a-black-titty-2138203| deadurl=no}} Timberlake had frequently mentioned admiring Jackson in many interviews during this time and throughout the following few years preceding the incident.{{cite web|title='N Sync Describes Hooking Up With Janet Jackson|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1430406/n-sync-describes-hooking-up-with-janet-jackson.jhtml|publisher=MTV News|date=August 10, 1998|accessdate=April 1, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Chat Transcripts: Justin|url=http://www.angelfire.com/ny2/nsyncandbsboysrfyne/justinchat.html|publisher=[[Angelfire]]|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} When asked who he thought was "the sexiest woman on the planet", Timberlake had said "I've thought Janet Jackson has nothing but [[sex appeal]], so I'd probably say her."{{cite web|title=Justin article|url=http://www.angelfire.com/me2/NSYNCLane/justinarticle.html|publisher=Angelfire|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Timberlake later asked Jackson to sing backing vocals on "(And She Said) Take Me Now", a song from his debut solo album ''[[Justified (album)|Justified]]'' which was initially planned to be released as a single, commenting "I wrote the chorus from a girl's perspective, and I just thought we should get a female on the part. Her name was the first that popped up in my head just because I love her voice. It sounds like feathers. I mean, she sounds like an angel."{{cite web|title=Timberlake, Janet Jackson Make Sexy Pair On Justified|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1457770/janet-gets-sexy-on-justin-cd.jhtml|publisher=MTV News|date=September 25, 2002|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} ==Incident== During the halftime show, Jackson performed a medley of hits, beginning with "[[All for You (Janet Jackson song)|All for You]]", "[[Rhythm Nation]]" and a brief excerpt of "[[Rhythm Nation 1814|The Knowledge]]" before surprise guest Timberlake appeared to perform a duet of his song "[[Rock Your Body]]" with Jackson.{{cite web|title=Janet Jackson – Biography|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p4572|pure_url=yes}}|author=Steve Huey|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|year=2008|accessdate=March 9, 2008}}{{cite news|title=CBS Apologizes for Jackson Breast-Flash|url=http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/S/SUPER_BOWL_JACKSON?SITE=CACRU&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|work=Associated Press|date=February 2, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040202201416/http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/S/SUPER_BOWL_JACKSON?SITE=CACRU&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=February 2, 2004}} Also published by CNN.com as "[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/football/nfl/specials/playoffs/2003/02/01/bc.fbn.superbowl.jackso.ap/index.html CBS apologizes for halftime breast-baring]". The performance featured several suggestive dance moves by both singers, and as Timberlake reached his final line of "Rock Your Body", "I'm gonna have you naked by the end of this song", Timberlake pulled off a part of Jackson's costume, revealing her right [[breast]], partially covered by a piece of [[Nipple shield (jewelry)|nipple jewelry]], for less than a second (after which the CBS broadcast immediately cut to an aerial view of Reliant Stadium). MTV's CEO [[Tom Freston]] claimed in an interview with the [[Reuters]] news agency that the exposure was a stunt orchestrated by Jackson.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/10/23/everything-you-forgot-about-janet-jackson-and-justin-timberlakes-2004-super-bowl-controversy/|title=Analysis {{!}} Everything you forgot about Janet Jackson and Justin Timberlake’s 2004 Super Bowl controversy|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}} Jackson's [[publicist]] stated the performance ending was only supposed to reveal Jackson's red lace bra, though the lace undergarment was accidentally removed along with the outer layer.{{cite web|title=In the beginning, there was a nipple|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/feature/story/_/id/10333439/wardrobe-malfunction-beginning-there-was-nipple|author=Marin Cogan|work=[[ESPN the Magazine]]|date=January 28, 2014|accessdate=January 30, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Fallout|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,586683,00.html|author=Gary Susman|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=February 3, 2004|accessdate=October 3, 2013}} ==Responses== {{Quote box|width=30%|align=left|quote="It's truly embarrassing for me to know that 90 million [140 million] people saw my breast, and then to see it blown up on the Internet the size of a computer screen ..." "But there are much worse things in the world, and for this to be such a focus, I don't understand".|source=– Jackson on Super Bowl incident.}} MTV stated, "The tearing of Janet Jackson's costume was unrehearsed, unplanned, completely unintentional and was inconsistent with assurances we had about the content of the performance. MTV regrets this incident occurred and we apologize to anyone who was offended by it." The network also said, "Our goal with the Super Bowl Halftime show was to produce an entertaining stage experience with a positive message about empowerment and voting. We are disappointed that this message has been overshadowed by the unfortunate incident".{{cite web|title=Janet Apologizes, Says Super Bowl Stunt Went Too Far|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1484766/janet-apologizes-super-bowl-stunt.jhtml|publisher=MTV News|date=February 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} A statement from CBS read, "We attended all rehearsals throughout the week and there was no indication that any such thing would happen. The moment did not conform to CBS broadcast standards and we would like to apologize to anyone who was offended." Viacom President [[Mel Karmazin]] said that while the company can be proud of 99% of what people saw on the broadcast, it understands "what a difference one percent can make". NFL Commissioner [[Paul Tagliabue]] said the show produced by MTV, which like CBS, was owned by Viacom at the time (before the two networks were respectively separated into [[Viacom]] and [[CBS Corporation]], both controlled by [[National Amusements]], in December 2005), fell far short of the "tasteful, first-class entertainment" the league expected. [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]] [[List of chairmen of the Federal Communications Commission|Chairman]] [[Michael Powell (attorney)|Michael Powell]], appearing before a Senate panel, called the Super Bowl incident "a new low for prime time television".{{cite web|title=Janet In Semi-Revealing Topless Shot On New CD |url=http://www.wjactv.com/entertainment/2840516/detail.html |publisher=[[WJAC-TV]] |date=November 2, 2004 |accessdate=April 1, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050228053257/http://www.wjactv.com/entertainment/2840516/detail.html |archivedate=February 28, 2005 }}{{cite news|title=Moonves ready to play hardball in Viacom split|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-09-16/business/0509160202_1_leslie-moonves-cbs-and-upn-radio-division-infinity-broadcasting|author=Phil Rosenthal|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|publisher=[[Tribune Publishing]]|date=September 16, 2005|accessdate=March 14, 2015}} [[Joe Browne]], [[Executive Vice President]] of the NFL, said, "We were extremely disappointed by elements of the MTV-produced Halftime show. They were totally inconsistent with assurances our office was given about the show. It's unlikely that MTV will produce another Super Bowl halftime." An hour-long MTV documentary titled "Making the Super Bowl Halftime Show" was scheduled to premiere the following week but was canceled before it ever aired and has never been broadcast subsequently.{{cite web|title='Making the Super Bowl Halftime Show' airs next weekend|url=http://news.janet-xone.com/2004/01/making-super-bowl-halftime-show-airs.html|publisher=JanetXone.com|date=January 26, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204053515/http://news.janet-xone.com/2004/01/making-super-bowl-halftime-show-airs.html|archivedate=February 4, 2014|df=}}{{cite web|title=MTV's "Making the Halftime Show" special may be cancelled|url=http://news.janet-xone.com/2004/02/mtvs-making-halftime-show-special-may.html|publisher=JanetXone.com|date=March 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204053349/http://news.janet-xone.com/2004/02/mtvs-making-halftime-show-special-may.html|archivedate=February 4, 2014|df=}} Salli Frattini, the executive producer for MTV who had planned the entire performance, recalled a phone call from the officiating booth that was her first indication something had gone wrong. Frattini was in a truck outside of Reliant Stadium celebrating the end of the 12-minute halftime performance, which they initially thought was a success. "We were like, 'Uh, we’re playing that back right now'", Frattini said. "There was lots of chaos in the truck, and we played it back and we were like, 'Oh, s[hit]. What just happened?'" Alex Coletti, another MTV producer, said he could not find Jackson after the performance. "I tried to get in touch to make sure she was okay", he said. "Her entire camp stopped answering the phones. I finally got to her tour manager, and they were already at the airport." Coletti assumed the singer was so mortified that she fled immediately, though later assumed the incident was a possible "set up", adding it was the last time he had spoken to her. Coletti's assumption is potentially another reason for Jackson's blacklisting on MTV in addition to other music channels and radio formats. An MTV representative confirmed the costume tear was conceptualized by the MTV staff, in which the show's producers mockingly ripped their clothing in response to Timberlake's closing lyric during rehearsals. This led to Jackson and Timberlake improvising the move, in which Timberlake tore off Jackson's kilt. Frattini stated, "When we did the original rehearsal, there was conversation about a fake skirt she would wear, and that Justin would actually pull open the skirt and take off the skirt. In rehearsal, they actually tried to rip open the skirt, which kind of went with the lyrics of the song". The production team then discussed another option, which led to the costume tearing, although the outfit was intended to stay in place. Jackson's representative explained the incident, saying, "Justin was supposed to pull away the rubber bustier to reveal a red lace [[bra]]. The garment collapsed and her breast was accidentally revealed."{{cite web|title=Janet Loses 'Lena; Justin Exits 'Motown'|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/46762/first-look-the-news-in-brief-february-3-2004|publisher=E!|date=February 24, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} CBS forced Jackson to release a video apology, and said "My decision to change the Super Bowl performance was made after the final rehearsal. MTV, CBS, [and] the NFL had no knowledge of this whatsoever and unfortunately, the whole thing went wrong in the end. I am really sorry if I offended anyone, that was truly not my intention". A written statement read, "The decision to have a costume reveal at the end of my halftime show performance was made after final rehearsals. MTV was completely unaware of it. It was not my intention that it go as far as it did. I apologize to anyone offended – including the audience, MTV, CBS and the NFL." Due to the event being accidental and unintentional, Jackson refused to release another apology statement to media outlets following this. Speaking to ''[[USA Today]]'', Jackson said, "It's truly embarrassing for me to know that 90 million [140 million] people saw my breast, and then to see it blown up on the Internet the size of a computer screen ... but there are much worse things in the world, and for this to be such a focus, I don't understand."{{cite news|title=Jackson steps out as 'Damita Jo'|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2004-03-29-janet-jackson-main_x.htm|author=Steve Jones|newspaper=USA Today|date=March 29, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Regarding continued backlash, she responded, "Who knows...Maybe they'll get mad at something that I do in my show, but at least it won't be new to me, since I've already gone through all of this. But I feel very positive that things are going to work out just fine. Everything happens for a reason." Publicist Marvet Britto stated, "Jackson embodies grace, style and integrity...She has never been known as a bad person." Britto describes Jackson’s videotaped apology as "impersonal", saying, "She has never been an impersonal artist, so it made it seem like she was guilty of something, and she wasn't. I would have had her and Timberlake apologizing side by side right from the beginning, since they performed side by side. Otherwise, it made the whole apology seem calculated and contrived." Jackson said of the apology, "I probably should have done it live. But there was so much going on at the time that I needed to just get it done. It is what it is. And it will pass, and I'm fine with it."{{cite web|title=Singer Janet Jackson preps for return to spotlight|url=http://www.today.com/id/4564858|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=March 22, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} At one point Jackson was scheduled to be interviewed about the incident by [[Diane Sawyer]] on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[newsmagazine]] ''[[Primetime (U.S. TV program)|Primetime]]'', however, the interview never came to fruition.{{cite web|title=Lloyd Grove's Lowdown: Waksal watchers, take note |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/front/story/167408p-146292c.html |newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York |date=February 24, 2004 |accessdate=April 1, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060613214545/http://www.nydailynews.com/front/story/167408p-146292c.html |archivedate=June 13, 2006 }} Jackson later briefly discussed the incident on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' and the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''. Jackson's outfit was designed by famed designer [[Alexander McQueen]], with Jackson later commenting "I don't blame him; he didn't rip it. Alexander is so great at what he does – he's a genius."{{cite news|title=Pop Tarts: Janet Jackson Says Man Behind 'Wardrobe Malfunction' a 'Creative Genius'|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/05/15/pop-tarts-janet-jackson-says-man-behind-wardrobe-malfunction-creative-genius/|author=Hollie McKay|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} In an interview with [[Australia]]'s ''[[Herald Sun]]'', Jackson commented on Timberlake (whom, as mentioned, Jackson had previously known personally and aided when she selected his former group 'N Sync to open for her ''Velvet Rope World Tour'' at the start of their career) distancing himself from the incident and seemingly changing with fame. "I really want to be honest about this, but I just feel that anything I say about him will be taken the wrong way", said Jackson. "I do think that Justin is very talented and that he has a very big career ahead of him. But he seems to have changed recently. He's gotten a bit cocky. You know, some people can handle success and some people can't. I'm starting to wonder if (the latter) is the case with Justin. And it hurts me to say that."{{cite book|title=Diva's Delight|author=Ritchie Yorke|work=[[Herald Sun]]|year=2004}} Producer [[Jimmy Jam]] revealed Jackson considered writing a song about the incident for her ''[[Damita Jo (album)|Damita Jo]]'' album, saying, "I don't know whether it will or not. But I have a feeling it probably will, because kind of whatever's happening in her life tends to be what she writes about [...] It'd be kind of interesting to see what her feeling is about it."{{cite news|title=KEEPING ABREAST OF THINGS?|url=http://www.nme.com/news/pixies/16118|agency=Associated Press|work=NME|date=February 10, 2004|accessdate=October 15, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016063132/http://www.nme.com/news/pixies/16118|archivedate=October 16, 2013|df=}} {{Quote box|width=35%|align=right|quote="[The furor] is hypocritical, with everything you see on TV. There are more important thing to focus on than a woman's body part, which is a beautiful thing. There's [[war]], [[famine]], [[homelessness]], [[AIDS]]. [...] They needed something to focus on instead of the war, and I was the perfect vehicle for that. [...] People are going to think what they want. It was an accident. It was not a stunt. That was embarrassing for me to have all those people see my breast."|source=– Jackson questioning media's focus on the event.}} Michael Musto of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' commented on the media's reaction to the incident, saying, "Janet became a symbolic [[Joan of Arc]] to burn at the stake. I actually do think her breast was used as a diversionary tactic – I'm not sure to distract from [[Iraq War|Iraq]] specifically – but it did distract from important issues, from things we actually should be appalled by. The story got an undue amount of attention when the fact is, nobody has proved how her breast harmed anyone."{{cite journal|title=Jackson Distraction|author=Matt Kalkhoff|journal=[[Genre (magazine)|Genre Magazine]]|page=50|date=October 2004}} Speaking to Robert Tannenbaum of ''[[Blender Magazine]]'', Jackson had strong, if guarded, views on the reactions, saying the furor "is hypocritical, with everything you see on TV. There are more important thing to focus on than a woman's body part, which is a beautiful thing. There's war, famine, homelessness, [[AIDS]]". The fact that it happened in an election year "did have a great deal to do with it. They needed something to focus on instead of [[Iraq War|the war]], and I was the perfect vehicle for that. People are going to think what they want. It was an accident. It was not a stunt. That was embarrassing for me to have all those people see my breast. That's like having your [[Human penis|penis]] hanging out in front of millions and millions of people."{{cite book|title=America's Most Wanted|author=Robert Tannenbaum|work=[[Blender Magazine]]|page=128|year=2004}}Janet declared the reaction to the accidental exposure as "contradictory", noting it to occur in an era where commercials for [[beer]] and [[Viagra]] are both "very sexual" and "practically omnipresent". Jackson also said the mishap was "not intentional" and a "costume accident", also commenting on some media outlets editing her taped apology, saying, "Sometimes they cut out that I said it was an accident...That's what the media does, that's the way they are because they want it to be told a different way."{{cite journal|title=Janet Speaks!|author=Lynn Norment|work=[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]|page=154|date=April 2004}} In ''[[Glamour Magazine]]'', Janet exclaimed, "It's hard to believe that there's a war and famine going on in the world and yet people made such a big deal about a breast. People said that it was done intentionally to sell records. Do you know what? I have never pulled a stunt. Why would you do that and have your album come out two months later? It doesn't make sense." In the ensuing months, Janet felt overwhelmed by the hostility towards her. "People think I'm immune to being hurt by what's said. They ask me questions that shock me. Not everybody is as strong as the next person and words can kill. People push you and you start to think, 'Can I handle this?' But I know I can."{{cite journal|title=The Truth About Me, Michael, & Nipplegate|author=Jordan Paramor|work=[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]|page=90|year=2004}} Immediately following the incident, Timberlake sounded unapologetic for his actions, telling ''[[Access Hollywood]]'', "Hey man, we love giving you all something to talk about." Timberlake released a statement saying "I am sorry that anyone was offended by the wardrobe malfunction during the halftime performance of the Super Bowl. It was not intentional and is regrettable."{{cite web|title=Super Bowl Halftime show generates controversy|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a13281/super-bowl-halftime-show-generates-controversy.html|work=Digital Spy|date=February 2, 2004|accessdate=September 30, 2013}} However, Timberlake was not required to film a video apology as Jackson was. Timberlake also addressed the incident at the [[Grammy Award|Grammy Awards]] the following week, which Jackson was banned from attending after being scheduled as a presenter, saying "I know it's been a rough week on everybody. What occurred was unintentional, completely regrettable and I apologize if you guys are offended."{{cite web|title=Janet Bags the Grammys|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/janet-bags-the-grammys-20040209|author=Andrew Dansby|work=Rolling Stone|date=September 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Timberlake gave an additional interview at the Grammy event and stated, "All I could say was, 'Oh, my God. Oh, my God,'" Timberlake said. "I looked at her. They brought a towel up on stage. They covered her up. I was completely embarrassed and just walked off the stage as quickly as I could. I'm frustrated at the whole situation. I'm frustrated that my character is being questioned. And the fact of the matter is, you know, I've had a good year, a really good year, especially with my music."{{cite web|title=Janet Nixed from Grammys|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/46775/janet-nixed-from-grammys|author=Sarah Hall|publisher=E!|date=April 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Timberlake later declared, "It was something that went wrong. Then I felt like, I'm going to show everyone that this was something that didn't affect me, and I'm going to show up at the Grammys."{{cite journal|title=The Birth of an Icon|author=David Freidman|journal=[[GQ (magazine)|GQ]]|date=September 2004}} He later said he was unable to attend most of the halftime rehearsals due to being on tour in [[Spain]], having only one day to rehearse.{{cite web|title=Janet Jackson Booted from Grammys, and Other Fallout|url=http://blogcritics.org/janet-jackson-booted-from-grammys-and/|author=Eric Olsen|work=Blogcritics|date=May 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} While promoting his sophomore album ''[[FutureSex/LoveSounds]]'' over two years later, Timberlake expressed regret for his behavior, saying, "In my honest opinion now ... I could've handled it better. ... I'm part of a community that consider themselves artists. And if there was something I could have done in her defense that was more than I realized then, I would have. But the other half of me was like, 'Wow. We still haven't found [[Rationale for the Iraq War | the weapons of mass destruction]] and everybody cares about this!'" He added, "I probably got 10 percent of the blame, and that says something about society ... I think that America's harsher on women. And I think that America is, you know, unfairly harsh on ethnic people."{{cite web|title=Justin Timberlake's Future Shock|url=http://www.mtv.com/bands/t/timberlake_justin/news_feature_081506/|author=Corey Moss|author2=John Norris|publisher=MTV News|date=August 15, 2006|accessdate=August 14, 2007| archivedate=September 1, 2006| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060901082304/http://www.mtv.com/bands/t/timberlake_justin/news_feature_081506/}} ===Media diversion=== Jackson suspected ulterior motives in the media's reaction, expressing, "It was just perfect timing to take people's focus off of other things. That's what happens, and it happened to me." Accounts from several university leaders and management groups offered a similar premise. Michael Rich, director of [[Harvard University|Harvard]]'s Center on Media and Child Health, exclaimed, "Here we have Michael Powell upset about the happening in the Super Bowl, but the same Powell has been unwilling to do anything about the [[Media violence research|violence on television]], where there has been much more research showing it has a harmful impact on kids." Robert Thompson, founding director of the Center for the Study of Popular Television at [[Syracuse University]], said, "Michael Powell is representing the Super Bowl like everybody in the family sits around knitting booties, or like, it's the [[Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade|Macy's Day Parade]]. [...] Come on. There's gambling, there's a lot of drinking, partying, a carnival atmosphere", he asserted. Jay Rosenthal, attorney for the [[Recording Artists' Coalition]], says the FCC's involvement was a smoke-screen, or a "[[sound bite]] attempt" by the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]-led commission to act as if it's doing something. "When it comes to [[media consolidation]] issues affecting consumers and artists, they don't care about that. But when it comes to indecency, after ignoring it for years, all of a sudden they're snapping to attention", he said. Simon Renshaw of management group [[The Firm, Inc.|The Firm]] stated it to be "inappropriate" that Powell is trying to distract people from the real issues of what's currently going on in the media. "What I find offensive is CBS' refusal to carry [[MoveOn.org]]'s ad during the Super Bowl", which pictured children working in factories to pay off the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]]'s budget deficit.{{cite web|title=A Flash of Political Opportunism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uw8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA69#v=onepage&q&f=false|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=February 14, 2004|accessdate=January 30, 2014}} The ''[[Boston Legal]]'' episode "Let Sales Ring" likened the incident to being used as a distraction, portraying a news corporation which used the mishap to attract attention over other important events in the media.{{cite web|title=Microsoft Word - BL01x16.doc|url=http://www.boston-legal.org/script/bl01x16.pdf|work=Boston Legal|year=2005|accessdate=January 30, 2014}} Daniel Kreps of ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' explained, "For the FCC, Nipplegate provided an opportunity to restore order and flex whatever power they had left. Faced with lax broadcast standards for [[cable television|cable TV]] and [[satellite radio]], as well as the absolute lawlessness of the Internet, the FCC becomes hell-bent on preserving common decency in the family-friendly realm of network television. Thus, screws are tightened everywhere under the body's jurisdiction: Tape delays are lengthened and more frequent and sexually suggestive performances are replaced by less provocative selections. While the aftermath of Nipplegate starts to fade, the FCC will continue to carry its torch for the next half-decade." Cynthia Fuchs of ''[[Popmatters]]'' stated, "It behooves TV producers and consumers to focus their attentions on significant "news", rather than the daily distractions offered up by politicians, performers, professional [[Spin (public relations)|spinners]], and journalists. Janet is not that person you watch on TV. And neither is anyone else."{{cite news|title=Distraction TV|url=http://www.popmatters.com/feature/040419-janetjackson/|author=Cynthia Fuchs|work=[[PopMatters]]|accessdate=April 19, 2004|date=January 30, 2014}} ===Powell's response=== A decade after the incident, former FCC chairman Michael Powell gave his first interview regarding Jackson's performance, saying Jackson was treated unfairly and the controversy, including his own reaction, was completely overblown. Powell stated, "I think we've been removed from this long enough for me to tell you that I had to put my best version of outrage on that I could put on. Part of it was surreal, right? Look, I think it was dumb to happen, and they knew the rules and were flirting with them, and my job is to enforce the rules, but, you know, really? This is what we're gonna do?" Powell also said the treatment of Jackson, who was lambasted for causing "an outrageous stunt", was unfair, and commented on Timberlake not receiving the same backlash. "I personally thought that was really unfair", he said. "It all turned into being about her. In reality, if you slow the thing down, it’s Justin ripping off her [[breastplate]]."{{cite web|title=In the Beginning, There Was a Nipple | url= http://espn.go.com/espn/feature/story/_/id/10333439/wardrobe-malfunction-beginning-there-was-nipple|work=[[ESPN The Magazine]] | first=Marin|last= Cogan|date=January 28, 2014|accessdate=June 27, 2016| archivedate=January 28, 2014 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140128191518/http://espn.go.com/espn/feature/story/_/id/10333439/wardrobe-malfunction-beginning-there-was-nipple | deadurl=no}} ==Public reaction== ===United States=== In the United States, the exposure of Jackson's breast by Timberlake led to much media attention and headlines, in which it was sometimes referred to as "Nipplegate".{{cite news |title=Jackson 'Nipplegate' illustrates the danger of chilling free speech|author=Julie Hilden|publisher=CNN|date=February 20, 2004|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/LAW/02/20/findlaw.analysis.hilden.jackson/|accessdate=July 27, 2007}} The socially conservative media watchdog group [[Parents Television Council]] (PTC) issued a statement that same day condemning the halftime show, announcing that their members would file indecency complaints with the FCC and the council supported the Commission's decision to investigate the halftime show immediately.{{cite press release|title=PTC Outraged with CBS' Raunchy Super Bowl|url=http://www.parentstv.org/ptc/publications/release/2004/0202.asp|publisher=[[Parents Television Council]]|date=February 2, 2004|accessdate=July 27, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210233301/http://www.parentstv.org/ptc/publications/release/2004/0202.asp|archivedate=December 10, 2006}} In addition, the FCC received nearly 540,000 complaints from Americans, with the PTC claiming responsibility for around 65,000 of them.{{cite web|title=Broadcast Indecency Campaign|url=http://www.parentstv.org/PTC/fcc/Complaints.asp|publisher=Parents Television Council |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503021051/http://www.parentstv.org/PTC/fcc/Complaints.asp|archivedate=May 3, 2007}} In its appeal to the Third Circuit Court, CBS disputed how many of the complaints were filed by individual, non-organized viewers.{{cite web|title=Countdown Supplemental|url=http://thenewshole.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2008/07/22/1216282.aspx|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=July 22, 2008|accessdate=July 25, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803081500/http://thenewshole.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2008/07/22/1216282.aspx|archivedate=August 3, 2008|df=}} Columnists [[L. Brent Bozell III]] (who also founded the Parents Television Council) and [[Phyllis Schlafly]] also expressed criticism of the halftime show in their weekly columns. [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] senator [[Zell Miller]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], both on the floor of the [[United States Senate]] and in an editorial on [[Salon.com]], denounced the halftime show as what he perceived as declining morality in America. The day immediately following the Super Bowl, then-FCC chairman Michael Powell ordered an investigation into the halftime show..{{cite news|title=Janet Jackson Apologizes for Bared Breast |url=http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/S/SUPER_BOWL_JACKSON?SITE=MAHYC&SECTION=BUSINESS&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|author=Nekesa Mumbi Moody|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=February 3, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040203025228/http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/S/SUPER_BOWL_JACKSON?SITE=MAHYC&SECTION=BUSINESS&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=February 3, 2004}} Also published by CNN.com as "[http://www.cnn.com/2004/US/02/02/superbowl.jackson/ Apologetic Jackson says 'costume reveal' went awry]". Timberlake told CBS [[owned-and-operated station]] [[KCBS-TV]] in [[Los Angeles]] a few days following the Super Bowl that even his own family was offended by the mishap at the end of the halftime show.{{cite news|title=Timberlake says own family offended by Super Bowl costume stunt|agency=Associated Press|date=February 4, 2004}} Also published by Yahoo! Music as "[https://web.archive.org/web/20061112214545/http://music.yahoo.com/read/news/12176775 Timberlake: Family Offended by Super Bowl]". However, an [[Associated Press]] poll taken nearly three weeks after the Super Bowl found that although 54% of American adults considered the exposure distasteful, only 18% supported the FCC's investigation.{{cite news|title=Poll: Janet Jackson Act Not Federal Case|url=http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AP_POLL_JANET_JACKSON?SITE=NJASB&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|author=Will Lester|work=Associated Press|date=February 21, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040312001041/http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AP_POLL_JANET_JACKSON?SITE=NJASB&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=March 12, 2004}} Film director [[Spike Lee]], speaking at [[Kent State University at Stark]] on February 3, called the incident a "new low" in entertainment.{{cite news|title=Spike Lee says Janet Jackson's breast baring a 'new low' for entertainers|url=http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/features/20040204-0213-superbowl-jackson.html|author=David Bauder|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=[[U-T San Diego]]|date=February 4, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040411114159/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/features/20040204-0213-superbowl-jackson.html|archivedate=April 11, 2004}} CNN.com published this story in an earlier version as "[http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/04/jackson.apology.ap/index.html Janet Jackson takes responsibility for breast-baring] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231165752/http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/04/jackson.apology.ap/index.html |date=2007-12-31 }}". The Super Bowl controversy was also a subject of humor on all of the [[late-night talk show]]s. For example, CBS's own ''Late Show with David Letterman'' mocked the incident all week following the Super Bowl. Host [[David Letterman]] jokingly commented on the controversy the day after the Super Bowl that he "was happy to see this thing happen ... because that meant for one night I wasn't the biggest [[Idiot (usage)|boob]] on CBS".{{cite episode|title=Show #2114|url=http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/video_player/index/php/891894.phtml|series=[[Late Show with David Letterman]]|network=[[CBS]]|airdate=February 2, 2004 |transcript=Transcript|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070515053217/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/video_player/index/php/891894.phtml|archivedate=May 15, 2007|transcripturl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930235809/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/wahoo/index/php/20040202.phtml}} The next day, he also joked that President [[George W. Bush]] formed a "Department of Wardrobe Security" to prevent further wardrobe malfunctions.{{cite episode|title=Show #2115 |series=Late Show with David Letterman |network=CBS |airdate=February 3, 2004 |url=http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/video_player/index/php/893669.phtml |transcripturl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930232152/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/wahoo/index/php/20040203.phtml |deadurl=yes |transcript=Transcript|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181654/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/video_player/index/php/893669.phtml |archivedate=September 30, 2007 }} On February 4, Letterman opened his monologue by joking about having a wardrobe malfunction.{{cite episode|title=Show #2116 |series=Late Show with David Letterman |network=CBS |airdate=February 2, 2004 |url=http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/video_player/index/php/893259.phtml |transcripturl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930223255/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/wahoo/index/php/20040204.phtml|transcript=Transcript |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930200928/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/video_player/index/php/893259.phtml |archivedate=September 30, 2007 }} Additionally, the [[Top 10 list (David Letterman)|Top Ten Lists]] featured on the program on that same night{{cite episode|title=Show #2117 |url=http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/top_ten/index/php/20040206.phtml |series=Late Show with David Letterman |serieslink=Late Show with David Letterman |network=CBS |airdate=February 6, 2004 |transcripturl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001000157/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/wahoo/index/php/20040206.phtml |deadurl=yes |transcript=Transcript|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930232016/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/top_ten/index/php/20040206.phtml |archivedate=September 30, 2007 }} briefly referenced the incident. Jackson's appearance on the ''Late Show'' the following month increased the show's ratings 20% from the program's usual weeknight opener.{{cite web|title=Janet Flashes Dave's Ratings|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/47147/janet-flashes-dave-s-ratings|author=Joel Ryan|publisher=E!|date=March 30, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} [[Larry King]] also stated Jackson jokingly gave him a pair of suspenders with open holes around the nipples, commenting "I wore them once, they were cute."{{cite news|title=A Brief History of Suspenders|url=http://content.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,2037331,00.html|author=Claire Suddath|work=Time|date=December 16, 2010|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} Democratic presidential candidate [[Howard Dean]] called the FCC's investigation "silly", commenting "In general, I think the FCC does have a role in promoting some reasonable standard of decency. However, considering what's on television these days, I think the FCC is being pretty silly about investigating this." Dean added "I don't find it terribly shocking relative to some of the things you can find on standard cable television. I think the FCC probably has a lot of other things they should be pursuing."{{cite web|title=Howard Dean calls FCC probe 'silly'|url=http://news.janet-xone.com/2004/02/howard-dean-calls-fcc-probe-silly.html|publisher=JanetXone.com|date=February 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310135735/http://news.janet-xone.com/2004/02/howard-dean-calls-fcc-probe-silly.html|archivedate=March 10, 2014|df=}} ''[[South Park]]'' (aired on [[Comedy Central]], a sister network to CBS at the time, and to MTV through Viacom) took aim at the hysteria in its eighth season premiere, "[[Good Times with Weapons]]", on March 17 of that year when [[Eric Cartman]] sneaks across a stage in the nude and later blames the incident on a "wardrobe malfunction". The townspeople are angered by Cartman's display, rather than feeling concern for a badly injured and disoriented character ([[Butters Stotch|Butters]]) who is also present on stage – a reference to the American culture's acceptance of violence while maintaining a taboo against nudity.{{cite web|title=The Secrets of 'Good Times With Weapons'|url=http://www.spscriptorium.com/Season8/E801secrets.htm|publisher=Spscriptorium.com|accessdate=November 29, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140619205632/http://www.spscriptorium.com/Season8/E801secrets.htm|archivedate=June 19, 2014|df=}} During the 2004 [[MTV Video Music Awards]], comedian [[Dave Chappelle]] joked that his appearance on the VMAs was "the biggest mistake [MTV made] since [they] put Janet Jackson on the Super Bowl."{{cite web|title=Toned Down Awards Shows|url=http://archive.mr.org/BozellColumns/entertainmentcolumn/2004/col20040902.asp|author=L. Brent Bozell III|work=[[Media Research Center]]|publisher=[[Creators Syndicate]]|date=September 2, 2004|accessdate=February 1, 2008}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''[[Family Guy]]'' also did an episode based around the "wardrobe malfunction" and the FCC's crackdown on "indecent" content, with one scene parodying the incident directly.{{cite web|title=Family Guy: PTV (2005) - Synopsis|url=http://movies.msn.com/movies/movie-synopsis/family-guy-ptv/|publisher=[[MSN]]|accessdate=November 29, 2013}} The fourth season episode "[[PTV (Family Guy)|PTV]]" involved actor [[David Hyde Pierce]] having a trouser malfunction at the [[Emmy Award|Emmys]]. The FCC's sudden crackdown on indecent material on television leads an angered [[Peter Griffin]] to start his own network with looser content standards, PTV, on which later in the same episode, he presents a show called the "Side Boob Hour" which among other risque programs he puts on leads his objected wife [[Lois Griffin|Lois]] to call the FCC to crack down on PTV (leading to the implication of the FCC also regulating what his family says and does). The halftime show continued to be a subject of discussion in 2005. At the beginning of 2005, the parody newspaper ''[[The Onion]]'' ran as its headline article for January 26, 2005, "U.S. Children Still Traumatized One Year After Seeing Partially Exposed Breast On TV". The article's satirical target was the nation's reaction to the incident, rather than the incident itself.{{cite web|title=U.S. Children Still Traumatized One Year After Seeing Partially Exposed Breast On TV|url=http://www.theonion.com/content/node/30883|work=[[The Onion]]|date=January 26, 2005|accessdate=November 29, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223085304/http://www.theonion.com/content/node/30883|archivedate=February 23, 2010|df=}} On February 1, 2005, exactly one year after the halftime show, the PTC released a report titled ''MTV Smut Peddlers: Targeting Kids with Sex, Drugs, and Alcohol'', covering MTV programming during the network's "Spring Break" week from March 20 to 27, 2004, accusing MTV of irresponsibly promoting sex, drugs and alcohol to impressionable youth. In response to the report, MTV network executive Jeannie Kedas argued that the report "underestimates young people's intellect and their level of sophistication."{{cite news|title=PTC Doesn't Want its MTV|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/500535-PTC_Doesnt_Want_Its_MTV.php|author=John Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=February 1, 2005|accessdate=March 15, 2015}} On February 6, however, ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' columnist [[Frank Rich]] argued that censorship on television was becoming more prevalent following the halftime show in his February 6, 2005 column "The Year of Living Indecently". Examples he cited included more than 60 ABC-affiliated stations (including those owned by the [[E. W. Scripps Company]], [[Hearst Television|Hearst-Argyle Television]] and [[Cox Media Group|Cox Broadcasting]]) refusing to broadcast ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'' due to the [[profanity]] prevalent throughout the film, which was to be aired unedited in its entirety by the network, and [[PBS]] editing obscene language out of certain programs such as the British terrorist drama ''[[Dirty War (film)|Dirty War]]''.{{cite news|title=The Year of Living Indecently|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/06/arts/06rich.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|author=[[Frank Rich]]|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 6, 2005|accessdate=November 25, 2007}} The [[ESPN]] series ''[[Playmakers]]'' was also immediately forced to be canceled by the NFL following the incident.{{cite news|title=PRO FOOTBALL; Citing N.F.L., ESPN Cancels 'Playmakers'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/05/sports/pro-football-citing-nfl-espn-cancels-playmakers.html|author=Richard Sandomir|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 2, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Washington Redskins: Spin Control Can't Save Dan Snyder from Bringing Down NFL|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1810475-washington-redskins-spin-control-cant-save-dan-snyder-from-bringing-down-nfl|author=Stephen Sonneveld|work=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=October 14, 2013|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} A commercial from [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]], which depicted a man opening a beverage on the outfit's breastplate and tearing it before it was worn, was intended to be aired during [[Super Bowl XXXIX]] the following year, but was pulled before its broadcast.{{cite web|title=Budweiser 'Wardrobe Malfunction' Ad pulled from Superbowl [sic] but available via Wizbang|url=http://wizbangblog.com/content/2005/01/28/budweiser-wardr.php|work=Wizbang|date=January 26, 2005|accessdate=November 8, 2010}}{{YouTube|title=Budweiser: "Wardrobe Malfunction" Ad|id=xC3o-M1UgtA}} {{Retrieved|accessdate=November 8, 2010}} ===Canada=== In [[Canada]], where the Super Bowl telecast was broadcast by the [[Global Television Network]], the incident passed largely without controversy: only about 50 Canadians complained about the incident to the [[Canadian Broadcast Standards Council]] (CBSC).{{cite web|title= |url=http://www.cbsc.ca/english/cbscdocs/submissions/BroadcasterMarchApril04.pdf |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcast Standards Council]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060529013751/http://www.cbsc.ca/english/cbscdocs/submissions/BroadcasterMarchApril04.pdf |archivedate=May 29, 2006 }} The CBSC received roughly twice as many complaints about other aspects of the Super Bowl broadcast, including music and advertising issues (though some were expected complaints about [[Canadian content]]/[[simultaneous substitution|simsub]] issues preventing viewing of the popular American advertisements, which is a common issue among Canadian viewers of the Super Bowl to the present day).{{cite web|title=CBSC Annual Report 2003-2004 |url=http://www.cbsc.ca/english/cbscdocs/annreports/CBSC_Annual_Report_2003-2004.pdf |publisher=Canadian Broadcast Standards Council |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705073114/http://www.cbsc.ca/english/cbscdocs/annreports/CBSC_Annual_Report_2003-2004.pdf |archivedate=July 5, 2007 }} Professor [[Robert Thompson (professor)|Robert Thompson]], director of the Center for the Study of Popular Television at [[Syracuse University]], stated: "I know many people in other countries are scratching their heads and thinking 'What in the world is the big fuss over there?'"{{cite news|title=US apoplexy over Jackson flash|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3456497.stm|author=Peter Bowes|publisher=BBC News|date=February 4, 2004|accessdate=May 17, 2008}} ===New Zealand=== New Zealand news outlets re-broadcast the "nipplegate" moment (some in slow motion) with commentary explaining that American ultra-conservatives had made the incident into a major controversy. The nation's largest newspaper, the New Zealand Herald, ran an op-ed from a New Zealander living in the US detailing his bafflement at his American friends, who had expressed outrage at the glimpse of nipple while supporting their country's invasion of Iraq and being fans of the television show ''[[Sex and the City]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=3547932|title=Roger Franklin: Double standards rife in America's fickle society - World - NZ Herald News|work=The New Zealand Herald}} ===Legal action=== On February 4, Terri Carlin, a banker residing in [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]], [[Tennessee]], filed a [[class action]] lawsuit against Jackson and Timberlake on behalf of "all American citizens who watched the outrageous conduct". The lawsuit alleged that the halftime show contained "sexually explicit acts solely designed to garner publicity and, ultimately, to increase profits for themselves". The lawsuit sought maximum [[punitive damages|punitive]] and compensatory damages from the performers. Carlin later dropped the lawsuit.{{cite news|title=Woman drops lawsuit over Super Bowl halftime show |url=http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/apnews/stories/021004/D80KH9900.shtml |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=Jacksonville Times-Union |date=February 10, 2004 |accessdate=July 27, 2007 }} Also published on CNN.com as "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070706171736/http://www.cnn.com/2004/LAW/02/10/jackson.fallout.ap/index.html Woman drops lawsuit over Jackson peep show]". Three months later, Eric Stephenson, a lawyer from [[Farmington, Utah|Farmington]], [[Utah]], filed a US$5,000 lawsuit in [[small-claims court]] against Viacom for [[false advertising]] of the Super Bowl halftime show, as he, the father of three young children, claimed that pre-game advertising led him to believe that the halftime show would consist of [[marching band]]s, balloons and a patriotic celebration.{{cite web|title=Janet's exposure prompts lawsuit|url=http://www.sltrib.com/2004/May/05222004/utah/168709.asp|author=Elizabeth Neff|newspaper=[[Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=May 22, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040603025907/http://www.sltrib.com/2004/May/05222004/utah/168709.asp|archivedate=June 3, 2004}} The lawsuit was rejected because Stephenson should have filed a [[Federal government of the United States|federal]] lawsuit or complaint to the FCC, which was already investigating the halftime show.{{cite news|title=Attorney loses lawsuit over Super Bowl show|agency=Associated Press|date=May 27, 2004}} Also published by Yahoo! Music as "[https://web.archive.org/web/20060908042803/http://music.yahoo.com/read/news/12176746 Judge Rules Against Super Bowl Viewer]". [[AOL|America Online]], the [[Internet service provider]] that sponsored the halftime show, demanded a refund of the approximately US$7.5 million that it paid to sponsor and advertise on the halftime show. However, no other advertisers of the Super Bowl had similar demands.{{cite news|title=AOL demands $10m refund after Jackson mishap|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/article1012828.ece|author=Nic Hopkins|newspaper=[[The Times (London)|The Times]]|location=London|date=February 6, 2004|accessdate=January 17, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612092211/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/article1012828.ece|archivedate=June 12, 2011}} [[File:Fcc complaints and fines 2001-2004.JPG|thumb|500px|right|The halftime show led to a great spike in FCC-issued fines and received complaints compared to those from previous years.]] The incident triggered a rash of fines that the FCC levied soon after the Super Bowl, alleging that the context of the "wardrobe malfunction" was intended "to pander, titillate and shock those watching" because it happened within the lyrics within Timberlake's performance of ''Rock Your Body'': "Hurry up 'cause you're taking too long ... better have you naked by the end of this song."{{cite journal|title=COMPLAINTS AGAINST VARIOUS TELEVISION LICENSEES CONCERNING THEIR FEBRUARY 1, 2004, BROADCAST OF THE SUPER BOWL XXXVIII HALFTIME SHOW|url=http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-04-209A1.pdf|author=[[Michael Powell (attorney)|Michael Powell]], [[Michael Copps]], [[Kevin Martin (FCC)|Kevin Martin]], [[Jonathan Adelstein]]|publisher=[[Federal Communications Commission]]|date=September 22, 2004|accessdate=August 5, 2007}} In addition, the FCC cited a news article on MTV's website ([[MTV.com]]) claiming that the halftime show would promise "shocking moments"{{cite web|title=Janet Jackson's Super Bowl Show Promises 'Shocking Moments'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1484644/20040128/jackson_janet.jhtml|author=Shaheem Reid|publisher=MTV News|date=January 28, 2004|accessdate=August 5, 2007}} and that "officials of both CBS and MTV were well aware of the overall sexual nature of the Jackson/Timberlake segment, and fully sanctioned it – indeed, touted it as 'shocking' to attract potential viewers". CBS, however, argued that the exposure was unplanned,{{cite news|title=CBS to FCC: Halftime Show Finale Was a Surprise to Us, Too|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A35448-2004Nov8.html|author=Lisa de Moraes|newspaper=The Washington Post|page=C7|date=November 9, 2004|accessdate=August 5, 2007}} although in later statements CBS asserted that while the exposure was unplanned by CBS, it was deliberately planned by Timberlake and Jackson "independently and clandestinely".{{cite news|title=CBS warns of censorship if bare breast edict stays|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSN1142486520070911|author=Jon Hurdle|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=September 11, 2007}} On September 22, 2004, the FCC fined Viacom the maximum penalty of US$27,500 for each of the 20 CBS-owned television stations (including [[broadcast relay station#satellite stations|satellites]] of [[WFRV]] in [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]], [[WCCO-TV|WCCO]] in [[Minneapolis]] and [[KUTV]] in [[Salt Lake City]]; current CBS owned-and-operated station [[KOVR]] in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] at the time was owned by the [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]) for a fine totaling US$550,000, the largest ever placed against a television broadcaster at that time.{{cite press release|title=FCC proposes statutory maximum fine of $550,000 against Viacom-owned CBS affiliates for apparent violation of indecency rules during broadcast of Super Bowl halftime show|url=http://www.fcc.gov/eb/News_Releases/DOC-252384A1.html|publisher=[[Federal Communications Commission]]|date=September 22, 2004}} However, the Parents Television Council{{cite press release|title=FCC Falls Short in Fining CBS Affiliates for Indecent Super Bowl Show|url=http://www.parentstv.org/ptc/publications/release/2004/0922.asp|publisher=Parents Television Council|date=September 22, 2004|accessdate=July 27, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040923163142/http://www.parentstv.org/PTC/publications/release/2004/0922.asp|archivedate=September 23, 2004}} and even some of the FCC commissioners criticized the Commission for fining only 20 CBS stations, not all of them, for the halftime show. 66% of respondents to a March 2005 ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine poll believed that the FCC overreacted to the halftime show by fining CBS.{{cite news|title=The Decency Police|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1039700,00.html|author=[[James Poniewozik]]|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=March 20, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814053856/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C1039700%2C00.html|archivedate=August 14, 2007|deadurl=yes|df=}} On November 24, 2004, Viacom paid out US$3.5 million to settle outstanding indecency complaints and stated that it would challenge the US$550,000 penalty related to the incident, on the grounds that the broadcast was unintentional and thus exempt from indecency regulation.{{cite news|title=Viacom to pay record $3.5 million to settle FCC indecency cases|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/viacomfcc_11-24-04.html|work=[[PBS Newshour|The Newshour with Jim Lehrer]]|publisher=[[PBS]]|date=November 24, 2004}} In March 2006, the FCC affirmed that the Super Bowl halftime show was indecent,{{cite news|title=FCC Lowers $4 Million-Plus Indecency Boom|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/6316388-FCC_Lowers_4_Million-Plus_Indecency_Boom.php|author=John Eggerton|work=Broadcasting & Cable|date=March 15, 2006|accessdate=March 15, 2015}} so CBS paid the FCC's issued fine in July 2006 in order to take their appeal against their fine to federal court.{{cite web|title=Janet Jackson Case Gets Day In Court|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/6477436-Janet_Jackson_Case_Gets_Day_In_Court.php|author=John Eggerton|work=Broadcasting & Cable|date=September 11, 2007|accessdate=March 15, 2015}} CBS appealed the fine on September 17 at the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|U.S. Third Circuit Court of Appeals]] in [[Philadelphia]].{{cite web|title=It's FCC vs. CBS in Bowl Battle|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/6478766-Its_FCC_vs_CBS_in_Bowl_Battle.php|author=John Eggerton|work=Broadcasting & Cable|date=September 17, 2007|accessdate=March 15, 2015}} On July 21, 2008, the Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled{{cite web|title=CBS v. FCC: No. 06-3575|url=http://www.ca3.uscourts.gov/opinarch/063575p.pdf|publisher=United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|year=2008|access-date=2008-07-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725082623/http://www.ca3.uscourts.gov/opinarch/063575p.pdf|archive-date=2008-07-25|dead-url=yes|df=}} in favor of CBS, voiding the FCC's fine on the grounds that the enforcement involved a significant deviation from prior practice that was not announced as a clear policy change.{{cite news|title=Court tosses FCC 'wardrobe malfunction' fine|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/C/CBS_JANET_JACKSON?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|author=Joann Loviglio|work=Associated Press|date=July 21, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080730030102/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/C/CBS_JANET_JACKSON?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=July 30, 2008}}{{cite news|title=Appeals court throws out fine against CBS in 'wardrobe malfunction' incident|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/othersports/2008065154_cbs22.html|author=Joann Loviglio|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=July 22, 2008|accessdate=November 29, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110901095604/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/othersports/2008065154_cbs22.html|archivedate=September 1, 2011|df=}}{{cite web|title=United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit : No. 06-3575|url=http://www.ca3.uscourts.gov/opinarch/063575p.pdf|publisher=United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|accessdate=November 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320172132/http://www2.ca3.uscourts.gov/opinarch/063575p.pdf|archive-date=2014-03-20|dead-url=yes|df=}} On May 4, 2009, however, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] [[vacated judgment|vacated]] and remanded the case back to the Third Circuit for reconsideration in light of the previously decided ''[[Federal Communications Commission v. Fox Television Stations (2009)]]''.{{cite news|title=Lower Court Told to Revisit Ruling in Super Bowl Show|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/05/business/media/05fcc.html|author=David Stout|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 5, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324063529/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/05/business/media/05fcc.html?n=Top%2FReference%2FTimes+Topics%2FPeople%2FJ%2FJackson%2C+Janet%3Fref%3Djanetjackson|archivedate=March 24, 2011|deadurl=no|df=}}The Supreme Court ruled in [https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/050409zor.pdf 8–653, FCC, et al. v. CBS Corp., et al.] (08-653): "The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of ''FCC v. Fox Television Stations, Inc.'', 556 U.S. ___ (2009)." See ''[[Federal Communications Commission v. Fox Television Stations (2009)|FCC v. Fox Television Stations]]'' and https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/07-582.ZS.html On November 2, 2011, the Third Circuit Court ruled 2–1 that its earlier decision was correct, citing that the broadcast was legal under the FCC's then-current policy of allowing "fleeting" indecency on the airwaves, and that it was unfair of the FCC to change the policy retroactively.{{cite news|title=CBS Ruling on Janet Jackson’s Super Bowl Exposure Upheld by Appeals Court|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-11-02/cbs-ruling-on-janet-jackson-s-super-bowl-exposure-upheld-by-appeals-court.html|author=Sophia Pearson|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=January 19, 2012}} On June 29, 2012, the Supreme Court declined an FCC appeal.{{cite web|title=The 10 Best Super Bowl Halftime Shows|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/the-10-best-super-bowl-halftime-shows-20130131/6-janet-jackson-justin-timberlake-jessica-simpson-nelly-p-diddy-kid-rock-super-bowl-xxxviii-2004-0804366|work=Rolling Stone|date=January 31, 2013|accessdate=September 30, 2013}} ==Other controversies== ===Commercials=== Prior to the broadcast, CBS rejected the MoveOn.org [[Super Bowl advertising|Super Bowl ad]] ''[[Bush in 30 Seconds]]'' because it was deemed too controversial. CBS stated that it had a "decades-old" policy of rejecting advertisements regarding "controversial issues of public importance", although MoveOn charged that the networks had previously accepted similar advertisements from other groups.{{cite news|title=Censored at the Super Bowl|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2004/01/29/censored-at-the-super-bowl.html|author=Jonathan Darman|work=[[Newsweek]]|via=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=January 30, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040309180112/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/4114703|archivedate=March 9, 2004}} The Super Bowl broadcast featured numerous commercials for [[erectile dysfunction]] medicines and advertisements for [[Anheuser-Busch]]'s [[Bud Light]] brand featuring a [[flatulence|flatulating]] horse and a dog attacking male [[genitalia]]; however, no politically charged advertisements appeared during the telecast.{{cite news|title=Monkey business|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/football/nfl/specials/playoffs/2003/02/02/commercials/index.html|author=Dan George|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=February 2, 2004|accessdate=July 25, 2008}} CBS, which also held the rights to [[Super Bowl XLIV]], later aired a commercial during that game featuring then-[[Florida Gators football|Florida Gators]] quarterback [[Tim Tebow]] and his mother that discreetly refer to their [[pro-life]] viewpoints. The ad, sponsored by [[Focus on the Family]], received similar controversy.Letter from [[Gloria Allred]] (Women's Equal Rights Legal Defense and Education Fund) to [[Leslie Moonves]] (CBS), "[http://www.radaronline.com/sites/default/files/cbs1.pdf Super Bowl Sunday Ad] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403042324/http://www.radaronline.com/sites/default/files/cbs1.pdf |date=2012-04-03 }}", January 28, 2010.{{cite news|title=Nothing wrong with Tebow Super Bowl ad|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/OPINION/02/06/martin.tebow.superbowl.ad/|author=[[Roland S. Martin]]|publisher=CNN|date=February 8, 2010|accessdate=May 24, 2010}} In a league-mandated policy meant to clear the airwaves of such advertisements, the NFL announced that those types of commercials would not air again during Super Bowl broadcasts (the league ended an advertising relationship with [[Levitra]] in March 2007 as an official league sponsor).{{cite news|title=My, how television commercials have evolved|url=http://www.journal-news.com/l/content/oh/story/living/2007/06/29/ddn063007lifechristy.html|author=Christy Reynolds|newspaper=[[Hamilton Journal-News]]|date=June 30, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706052633/http://www.journal-news.com/l/content/oh/story/living/2007/06/29/ddn063007lifechristy.html|archivedate=July 6, 2007|df=}} In January 2005, [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], the network that carried Super Bowl XXXIX under the NFL's alternating network contract for the championship game, rejected an advertisement for the cold remedy [[Airborne (dietary supplement)|Airborne]] that briefly featured the naked buttocks of veteran actor [[Mickey Rooney]]. ===Streaking=== Moments after the Jackson-Timberlake tangle, [[Streaking|streaker]] [[Mark Roberts (streaker)|Mark Roberts]] added to the controversial halftime by running around the field naked except for some writing on his body which read "SUPER BOWEL" on the front, an advertisement for an [[online betting]] website, and a well-placed [[G-string]] attached to half of a miniature football covering Roberts' genitals.{{cite news|title=Image|url=http://img.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2007/08_01/RobertsBase070807_468x749.jpg|work=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London|accessdate=November 29, 2013}} Part of Roberts' stunt was broadcast in the United States; CBS chose to keep its cameras in a wide-shot view of the stadium and use quick cutaways to players and coaches as Roberts ran around the field until players from both competing teams, the [[New England Patriots]] and the [[Carolina Panthers]], tackled him. [[Matt Chatham]], the Patriots' special teams expert and reserve [[linebacker]] initially knocked Roberts down, thus allowing stadium security and police to arrest Roberts and take him into custody.{{cite news|title=Linebacker levels Super Bowl streaker|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/2004/02/02/pro_403164.shtml|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=[[Augusta Chronicle]]|date=February 1, 2004|accessdate=July 27, 2007}} Also published by SI.com as "[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/football/nfl/specials/playoffs/2003/02/01/bc.fbn.superbowl.streak.ap/index.html Pats' linebacker levels Super Bowl streaker]." ===Other performers=== Aside from Jackson's exposure, minor controversy around the show's other performances included rappers [[Sean Combs|P. Diddy]] and [[Nelly]] gesturing towards their crotches{{cn|date=February 2018}}, stripping [[cheerleaders]]{{cn|date=February 2018}}, and musician [[Kid Rock]] appearing in a poncho made from a slit [[Flag of the United States|American flag]], which he later threw towards the audience.{{cite web|title=VFW slams Kid Rock for flag poncho|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2004/02/04/Artsandentartainment/VFW_slams_Kid_Rock_fo.shtml|author=Justin George|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=February 4, 2004|accessdate=August 23, 2013}} U.S. Senator Zell Miller complained that Kid Rock's outfit was a desecration of the American flag.{{cite news|title=|url=http://www.accessnorthga.com/detail-pf.php?n=176732|publisher=AccessNorthGA.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201232437/http://www.accessnorthga.com/detail-pf.php?n=176732|archivedate=2014-02-01|df=}} ==Aftermath and effects== ===Censorship and regulation of broadcasting=== Website Soap Opera Central speculated that the fallout from this incident may have had a subtle effect on [[daytime television]]. These television shows are known for "[[Love in the Afternoon (advertising campaign)|love in the afternoon]]" and regularly feature romantic couplings; shortly before the Super Bowl, the [[Procter & Gamble]] [[soap opera]]s ''[[As the World Turns]]'' and ''[[Guiding Light]]'' had gone as far as featuring rear male nudity during sexual scenes. After the Super Bowl controversy, FCC commissioner [[Michael J. Copps]] stated that it was time for a crackdown on inappropriate sexual content in daytime television, and indicated that he was reviewing whether soap operas were violating the agency's indecency prohibitions.{{cite news|title=FCC says soaps may need to be cleaned up|url=http://www.soapcentral.com/soapcentral/news/2004/0412-fcc.php|author=Dan J. Kroll|work=[[Soapcentral]]|date=April 8, 2004}} Two other major sporting events that followed the Super Bowl that year also were forced to censor their respective halftime shows following the incident. The [[Pro Bowl]], which would be played on February 8 at [[Aloha Stadium]] in Hawaii, originally was to feature singer [[JC Chasez]], who was a member of boy band 'N Sync as was Timberlake, sing the [[Star-Spangled Banner|National Anthem]] before the game and perform his hit song "[[Blowin' Me Up (with Her Love)]]" at [[halftime]]. However, the NFL did not allow Chasez to perform during halftime due to the sexually suggestive content of his chosen song (even though the game was carried by ESPN, which is not under the content purview of the FCC as it is a cable network, and therefore only self-regulates content as an advertiser-supported service), replacing it with traditional Hawai{{okina}}ian dancers.{{cite web|title=Justin 'Appalled' By Super Bowl Incident; NFL Nixes JC Appearance|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1484824/justin-appalled-by-super-bowl-incident.jhtml|author=Corey Moss|publisher=MTV News|accessdate=August 24, 2013|date=February 4, 2004}}{{cite web|title=JC Chasez Slams NFL After Being Cut From Pro Bowl Halftime|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1484842/jc-slams-nfl-after-being-cut-from-pro-bowl.jhtml|author=Corey Moss|publisher=MTV News|accessdate=August 24, 2013|date=February 5, 2004}} The [[2004 NBA All-Star Game]] also censored its act, despite being broadcast on [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]] (which in reiteration, is not bound by FCC content regulations as a cable network), having halftime performer [[Beyoncé|Beyoncé Knowles]] perform "[[Crazy in Love (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Crazy in Love]]" rather than "[[Naughty Girl (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Naughty Girl]]", which they feared would incite controversy given its sexual content. Jackson was in attendance at the game, and dressed conservatively.{{Harvard citation no brackets|Lane|2006|pp=47–48}} The networks that were to broadcast the [[46th Grammy Awards]] (CBS) and the [[76th Academy Awards]] (ABC), live events scheduled for February 8 and February 29 respectively, enhanced their broadcast delays to accommodate editing of inappropriate video in addition to audio.{{cite news|title=CBS to use 'enhanced' tape-delay for Grammys|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/03/grammys.tape.delay|publisher=CNN|date=February 4, 2004|accessdate=August 23, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040407194339/http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/03/grammys.tape.delay/|archivedate=April 7, 2004}}{{cite news|title=ABC to impose delay on Oscar telecast|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/Movies/02/05/sprj.aa04.abc.oscar.delay/|author=Matt Carey|publisher=CNN|accessdate=August 23, 2013|date=February 5, 2004}} Following these announcements, ''Guiding Light'' edited out nudity from an episode that had already been taped. A week later, the show's [[executive producer]] [[John Conboy]] was fired and replaced by [[Ellen Wheeler]]. All nine American network soaps began to impose an unwritten rule of avoiding any sort of risqué adult scenes, and in the months following, editors of soap opera periodical ''[[Soap Opera Digest]]'' wrote about how daytime television was losing its steam. [[NBC]] also re-edited a scene from an episode of its medical drama ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'' where paramedics were wheeling an elderly woman into the hospital, and her breast could be seen non-explicitly in the context of her injury and treatment.{{cite news|title=NBC's 'ER' Cuts Shot of Patient's Breast|url=http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/T/TV_ER_BREAST?SITE=FLTAM&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|author=Lynn Elber|work=Associated Press|date=February 4, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040223195103/http://customwire.ap.org/dynamic/stories/T/TV_ER_BREAST?SITE=FLTAM&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=February 23, 2004}} Even as late as [[Veterans Day (United States)|Veterans Day]] (November 11) of 2004, 65 ABC-affiliated stations pre-empted the uncut network presentation of the film ''Saving Private Ryan'' over concerns about the film's violent and profane content and FCC regulations. Benjamin Svetkey of ''Entertainment Weekly'' quoted L. Brent Bozell III and [[Peggy Noonan]] associating the mass pre-emption of ''Ryan'' with the halftime show incident.{{cite news|title=America is from Mars, Hollywood is from Venus|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,784915,00.html|author=Benjamin Svetkey|periodical=Entertainment Weekly|date=November 24, 2004|issue=794|ref=harv|postscript=}} The annual [[Victoria's Secret Fashion Show]] was cancelled for that year in reaction to the incident.{{cite news|title=Victoria's Secret is out|url=http://money.cnn.com/2004/04/12/news/fortune500/victorias_secret/index.htm|author=Joseph Lee|publisher=CNN|date=April 12, 2004|accessdate=May 24, 2010}} A petition was filed by a consortium of broadcasters (which included Viacom) and the RIAA over an FCC indecency ruling, regarding [[fleeting expletives]] uttered by [[Bono]] of [[U2]] when accepting an award at the [[60th Golden Globe Awards]] in 2003. It argued that the FCC had implemented a standard "that would allow it to censor all kinds of things — anything considered blasphemous, coarse or vulgar", and observed that many radio stations, especially [[rock music|rock]]-formatted stations, had been engaging in self-censorship by censoring or removing songs from their libraries, so that they would not run afoul of the stricter regulation.{{cite web|title=Media Fights for Free Speech|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/media-fights-for-free-speech-20040511|author=Damien Cave|work=Rolling Stone|date=November 5, 2004|accessdate=April 1, 2014}} [[Clear Channel Communications]] removed talk-radio host [[Howard Stern]] from several of its large-market radio stations within a month of the incident, citing the raunchy content of Stern's show. The FCC fined Clear Channel over allegedly indecent content on the [[Bubba the Love Sponge]] radio show.{{cite web|title=Clear Channel to pay record fine for indecency charges|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/clearchannelfine_06-09-04.html|work=The Newshour with Jim Lehrer|publisher=PBS|date=June 9, 2004|accessdate=July 27, 2007}} As a result of the incident, some networks established regulations requiring time delays of as much as five minutes for live broadcasts such as [[awards show]]s and sporting events.{{cite news|title=Oscar head angry at TV show delay|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/3478467.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=February 11, 2004}} In late 2004, the [[United States House of Representatives]] passed a bill to raise the maximum FCC fine penalty from said US$27,500 to US$500,000 per violation; the [[United States Senate]] voted to decrease it to US$275,000 per incident, with a cap of US$3 million per day.{{cite news|title=CBS Fined $550,000 for Jackson Stunt |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FCC_CBS?SITE=FLSTU&SECTION=ENTERTAINMENT |author=Jennifer C. Kerr |work=Associated Press |date=July 1, 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040928060305/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FCC_CBS?SITE=FLSTU&SECTION=ENTERTAINMENT |archivedate=September 28, 2004 }} Also published by CBSNews.com as "[https://web.archive.org/web/20040925012741/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/07/01/entertainment/main626925.shtml CBS Dealt Record Fine Over Janet]". By June 2006, the two houses reconciled the differences in fine levels, settling for a fine of US$325,000 per violation in the [[Broadcast Decency Enforcement Act of 2005]]. The incident also prompted tighter control over content by station owners and managers. Viacom, at the center of the controversy, also employed the controversial Howard Stern in its radio division (at the time called [[Infinity Broadcasting]]). The expanding control on content is said to be a contributing factor that drove Stern away from [[terrestrial radio]] and onto [[Sirius Satellite Radio]], and is sometimes credited as the media figure most responsible for introducing a new era in radio. It has also been reported that some teen-oriented awards shows in the summer of 2004 had also been purged of most sexual and profane content that had been perceived as staples in such awards telecasts in the past, including Fox's [[Teen Choice Awards]] and MTV's self-created Video Music Awards. Author Frederick S. Lane stated in an interview with John Eggerton of ''[[Broadcasting & Cable]]'' magazine that the controversy surrounding the halftime show was the primary inspiration for his 2006 book ''The Decency Wars: The Campaign to Cleanse American Culture'', which explains moral controversies in the American media over the years.{{cite web|title=Behind the Cultural Clean-Up|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/6368245-Behind_the_Cutural_Clean-Up.php|author=John Eggerton|work=Broadcasting & Cable|date=September 4, 2006|accessdate=April 19, 2008}} The Super Bowl itself would not feature a modern act for its halftime show for the next six years, opting instead for classic rockers such as [[Paul McCartney]], [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]], [[Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band]], and The Who (McCartney, the Stones and The Who were all part of the [[British Invasion]] of the 1960s). In fact, no women performed at the Super Bowl halftime show at all until [[The Black Eyed Peas]] performed in 2011. In 2012, during the halftime show for [[Super Bowl XLVI]], rapper [[M.I.A. (artist)|M.I.A.]] [[Finger (gesture)|pointed up her middle finger]] during her performance. That incident drew comparisons with the exposure of Janet Jackson's breast in the Super Bowl halftime show eight years prior.
